I wish the country well and am sorry to hear of the rising sea difficulties in places in Kiribati.

text:
Despite the economic benefit of having nature bequeting a country with sea in the sense that you have a big sea to easily ship your manufactured goods ( export ) and also import from other countries.

You have easy access to sea food such as fish, prawn, etc

it carries a lot of inconveniences too as houses located closer to the sea are threatened with floods, and other ecological problems.
Coastal states in Nigeria like Lagos, Ogun, Ondo, Delta, Bayelsa, Rivers, Akwa Ibom state suffer threat from the Atlantic Ocean.

Resident living around the big sea are threatened with flooding which often brings water into their home.

CLIMATE CHANGE HAS HAD TOO MANY EFFECT ON SO MANY COUNTRIES.

In Nigeria, for example, fulani herdsmen want to graze their cattle in the southern part of Nigeria and with struggle for control of land and water. It has resulted in so much killing of the indigenous people over their land.

Fulani herdsmen desire for land from the south for open grazing of cattle which is considered primitive is responsive for one of the crisis in Nigeria. 

As the indigenous people are opposed to giving out their land to killer fulani herdsmen.

Some of the fulani herdsmen that are committing the crimes such as destroy farmlands and crops, raping of women, and killing of farmers including kidnapping for ransom.

Some of this fulani herdsmen that are committing this crime are not from Nigeria as they came from neighbouring countries such as Cameroun, Niger, Chad, and Mali.

So this is the price Nigerian from the south are paying for climate change.
author: Nigeria Africa

text: ¬†@Michelle Sheaff¬† Michelle- i knew my hypothetical question to Greta's (and Al Gore's) conviction that human activites are to blame for the current climate change would draw a lot of knee-jerk non-answers like yours. I'm NOT denying that the climate changes. My question was simple: What, given the absence of billions of polluting human beings, caused the profound epoch of global warming 10,000 years ago? Not people, that's for sure. And you did nothing to even try to answer it, except to object to my query:  given the absence of billions of polluting human beings, < what DID cause the last period of global warming?  Asking the question seems perfectly reasonable to me, and no reason to get your panties all up in a bunch; just answer the question...
author: Patrick Branin

text: ¬†@Michelle Sheaff¬† I knew that my hypothetical question to Greta's conviction that human activites are to blame for climate change would draw a lot of knee-jerk non-answers like yours. text: It‚Äôs a heartbreaking thing to watch these beautiful, kind and gentle people are loosing their beautiful island home to a climate change. But I am so very proud of you those families, School children and people in general are doing something about saving their island in some ways, for example, the planting of Mangrove trees and the families who are doing their best to build walls around their homes to prevent the seawater from destroying their family homes. The most important and interesting thing about this documentary is that they the people of that island knows that their future is uncertain and yet they‚Äôre not giving up hope and leaving for another country but are dead serious to stay and work together to change for the better outcome of their island paradise. Thank you all beautifully people of Tarawa Island to tell your story and to witness the horror of the climate change is doing to your country as a whole. Stay strong and may the Lord keep you all safe and protected. God bless the people of Kiribati, my grandson‚Äôs mother is from Kiribati as well. üôèüòÇüå∫

text: Coral Islands sit on 'lenses' of fresh water. Water extraction will make the land sink and compact while increasing groundwater salinity and this is the same where ever water extraction is greater than water going in. In addition removal of vegetation that hold and retain soil or sand, such as mangroves will mean land will be swept away. Mangrove build land but they are on the retreat in many places because they are being removed. ALL pacific islands that are no longer active volcanically are subsiding and this has been understood for at least 150 years. If there is a global sea level rise problem then it will be evident globally everywhere and it isn't. Climate Change is repeated as the reason for the predicament at Kiribati and yet it is repeated as fact. This is not how facts are established. It just so happens that the date of this YouTube was just about the time of the last COP meeting which tries to extract wealth from industrial countries by projecting guilt. text: Charcoal, sand, and pebbles can be used(when layered, with more layers allowing for better filtering) to filter out both loose particles and insects/parasites from water. Boiling and condensing water will give you a source of salt and cleanse the water of bacterial issues, both will help you achieve cleaner water and deal with the multitude of issues drinking dirty water causes without needing expensive chemical solutions. Though unless you have a way to produced heat enough to vaporize water without burning down the island's natural plantlife(i.e. electricity produced via kinetic conversion using either a wind or water mill, or using solar energy), it wouldn't be the best idea.
author: XThexReaperX

text:
Not to sound condescending, but there is a guy who made an legitimate floating island out of trash, wooden pallets, tarps, and mangrove trees. I honestly believe that if the community utilized the same methods he showed, they could not only continue to live on their island, but also turn around and build up the land using those same methods. After all, like an iceberg, the bigger the manmade floating island gets(both in height and width), the more floatation it requires beneath it.

So what if you intentionally marooned these floating islands progressively further and further out from were the sea meets the land? There are a multitude of plants that help prevent erosion via their root systems. Hawaiian grass has roots that extend some 20 feet down and are as strong as steel. Coral can grow on any hard surface(including themselves), so crafting cement pillars(they don't have to be thick or particularly heavy, though the longer the better) to sink out in the waters with a couple pieces of coral around them would act as an excellent base for coral to grow off of and build a coastal wall/shelf to help keep the sand/soil from completely washing away with the tide.

text: Global change is cyclical and will soon change to global freezing as it did 50 years ago. What humans do is a grain of sand in the larger scheme of things. A single discharge or burp of a volcano emits more CO2 then the history of human civilization. CO2 is responsible for record plant and tree growth in recent years, it does warm the Earth but plant growth also cools it making it not as much a factor as volcanic activity. Until we can control plate tectonics and volcanoes, we can never control global warming or cooling. A carbon tax and these government agendas are profit making machines. If the spokespeople for global warming were at all worried about it then why would Obama and Al Gore etc etc buy beach front property. Why would banks give loans for Beach front property if it was imminent? People that claim to be helping only get rich off of us while promoting panic. The Earth will find a balance and then it will be a global cooling crisis.

text: The problem with estimating sea level rise is that the land itself may be sinking.  The islands in the Pacific are on a conveyor belt moving north and being subsumed into the crust while new islands form in the south. Fort Denison in Sydney has a long record of sea levels measurements and this must be an indicator of what is really happening around the world because all the oceans are linked.  Sea level in Sydney is rising at 0.65mm per year and it seems that Fort Denison is itself sinking at a rate of around 4mm per year which leaves a true rate of rise of around 0.15mm per year or less than an inch per century, and  is not the reason for the encroachment of the ocean on the Pacific Islands.  Add to this the fact that the oceans are a very large heat sink and respond to global warming only centuries after the atmosphere heats or cools and there is no way that the increase in CO2 is the cause of the rise.  As far as I can tell, the alarmism in this video is unwarranted.

text:
My God what a load of cobblers. One minute we're being told about how certain continents will join and merge in the next 250 million years. Then apparently, "climate change", which is massively overused in this video without being supported by scientific certainties, has destroyed this island since what? 1983? And it seems EVERYONE buys into it.

Apart from anything else we'll all be very dead by the time there's any serious long-term change to the climate, by which time everyone alive now, and their kids, and kid's kids and kid's kids kids will all be long dead. In other words, who cares? There's plenty more dangerous stuff that could destroy this planet way before a bit more sun and some melted ice makes a difference. If you even think about climate change you're either a politician or a gullible hippy.

text:
Around 7:00, I'm a really amateur scientist and I have bad news for these people.  Even if the entire world starting pulling CO2 (& equivalent gasses) out of the air today, the climate will still warm by about 1.5 degrees Celsius (edit: before we start to see a downward trend).

The most we can do is hazard mitigation.  Raising these homes 3 to 6 meters higher and building 10 meter storm walls.  This isn't economical for most of these homes. It's great that Fiji has sold land to Kiribati.

The sea level rising is inevitable.  Even if all carbon emissions ended today, we will see about 3 meter sea level rise.

It takes decades to affect the rate of global warming. It's not like an instant, on-off switch.  It will take decades or centuries to see a desired trend.

We could seed clouds with salt to increase their albedo, and we could end all CO2 equivalent emissions today and we will still see global warming happening for decades. This is scientific based reality.

text:
¬†@Carol Miller¬† Let's not get radical. We need to be rational & realistic. Global warming/climate change will not kill off all life, nor all humans. But it WILL disrupt many, will cost much money, and will kill some (up to max 10% of) people. Just as the Kiribaas have planned to relocate to Fiji (their gov't already bought land for that), many forward-thinking people are working in many ways/areas, to protect vulnerable populations. And in 30 years we'll need again more strict measures - and again another 30 years after that even more strict limits... until we eliminate most of our carbon-polluting. The core problem is, the poorest (and the most foolish) will suffer, even die. And it's fully unfair to punish the poorest/most innocent people/nations. We in the west need to change, and take responsibility. This requires accords -- and newer accords -- every 10 years, which each adjust targets/goals.

Any "Plan for Escape" is untenable! Where will we escape to? All other planetary bodies have more severe problems than our Terrestrial global warming. Also, let's focus, and never attack our own/thinking people who are on the "correct side" (solutions-oriented side) of this global problem. We must also educate (vigorously) the deniers!!! Things are NOT "too late". Climate science documented many recent instances of the Earth "healing" itself, although slowly -- and yes many ppl will still suffer. But as long as we fix our Carbon-polluting behaviors within the next ~100 years, it will not go into an irreparable/catastrophic cycle. Scientists have seen that every time we've corrected our carbon-polluting behaviors (during the last 30 years), the Earth repaired parts of its atmosphere within 5-10 years (but not entirely repaired - full self-repair will require longer times). Extremist/alarmist views is the same as infighting (attacking ourselves) - which effectively attacks scientists. Top experienced climate scientists do believe we have at least 3+ decades of time, though we must do more ASAP.

text:
Nature's "engineering and technology" is global warming. Nature uses many "engineering and technology" in parallel, even in conflict with itself. While mangroves slow erosion, other parts of nature work to erode that land. These forces find a balance, and then an island can remain stable. Yet mankind causes drastic disruptions in nature's balance - e.g. in our global atmosphere. Anyone can measure the trends, of how we imbalanced nature.

Hope is not enough. Hope is why so many are dying of COVID in hospitals, because many Americans eschew vaccines. Nature's virus is engineering its own survival. Nature wants/finds balance, to keep both viruses and animals/humans alive. Our vaccines shift that balance to give us the edge, and kill off the virus. Yet millions of Americans foolishly won't take the vaccine. They allow nature's virus to win, causing people to die.

text: Traditional wayfinding. Although the tradition now is almost extinct the two main signs for distant islands were the pattern of the waves (waves retracting from islands have a ripple effect of about 20-30km during high tides, and the colour of the lower part of clouds which reflected what was below them (greenish hues meant vegetation, bluish meant there is a lagoon a.k.a freshwater, the best islands had a tealish colour or a combination of both). Migrating birds also played a major part in land finding too. Food and water wasn't a major concern especially if it was a well prepared voyage. Kabubu and Kamaimai (preserved pandanus and coconut syrup) complemented the fish that was caught on board which was always eaten raw. Raw fish has a water content of 70-80%.

text: What no one seems to mention, is that the water may not be rising, but the land is sinking. Many areas of the planet have tectonic plates sliding under other plates. As they slide under, it gives the illusion that the water level is rising. There are cities from thousands of years ago in Greece and other places, now completely under water. I've lived in South Florida for the past 32 years, and over that time it appears the water level has only risen slightly based on the tidal action against seawalls that have been there for 50 years. I hate to tell you, but there's nothing we can do about it.

Looks to me like an island, such as this, that is basically an atoll that is at sea level, should never have been occupied with residents.  Our world has cycled for thousands of years.  People have migrated throughout history.  Now climate change is all the rage and activists are coming out of the woodwork.  I'm not a climate denier, but a realist that we have an ebb and flow of our environment and have had for thousands of years!  What kind of life is that to be packed into this little atoll that probably has no good infrastructure and they need education to stop having 6-8 children to overpopulate the place.  It's just not a big enough postage stamp.

Seems to me that there is no real future there and no jobs to sustain these people.  The men just seem to hang about and are having a lot of children that they can't support, or afford.  Seems an odd mentality to just hang onto a lifestyle that there is nothing productive to your life, or future and productivity for your children.

text: I've heard my partner mention that a lot of times when meeting my family lol. Kiribati is at the crossing point between Micronesia (light skin), Melanesia (dark skin) and Polynesia (brown skin). We were initially settled by Melanesians, followed by an Austronesian (South East Asian) migration from the west and a Polynesian migration from the south (Samoa) which happened over a course of 2,500-3,000 years. A diverse looking people with one culture and language. Apart from the ones you mentioned I also have relatives that have been mistaken to be Middle Eastern/Arab and South American too. Most people who are familiar though can tell Kiribati people apart from other Pacific Islanders from the higher cheekbones.

text:
Some common sense here since it's obviously lacking in the person that made this video.
The climate is going to change whether humans are here or not. Because the Earth has been changing since the beginning of its being and will continue long after humanity is gone. 
We have no effect on the climate, we are nothing but fleas to mother nature and she could shake us off like a bad cold. Because it is the nature of things and nature changes going through cycles humans have very little effect on that.
It is remarkably arrogant to think that we have that much control over the climate that again has been changing since the dawn of time and will continue to change until the end of time. Because the Earth is as alive as we are.
It is how the lands have changed in millions of years creating the mountains that move 2" per year, creating the Mariana trench which is constantly changing, creating the ice age.
It's also really pathetic to try to change your atmosphere to beat mother nature because she is going to wipe you away. Instead of fighting mother nature you should have respect for her and pick up and move from the places that she no longer wants you to be... Humans need to learn how to adapt to their world, instead of trying to make their world adapt to them. Mother nature will win every time. Nature is far smarter than Humanity.
More proof of this is in the fact that islands have risen and fallen in the sea since the beginning of time. Entire cultures have been lost to the Sea not because of human caused climate change but because climate change is the natural order of things. It is Mother Nature herself. Gaia

text:
It's such a terribly sad thing to see these beautiful islands being lost to erosion and rising seas. I see they blame the west but unfortunately all nations need to share the burden of the environmental impact we see today.

Yes the west created the car, the aeroplane, plastics and other such things.... But we ALL need to see the impact that these things are having on our environment. We need to stop using plastic for disposable purpose, reduce our waste, manufacturers need to stop using plastic in their wrappers and packaging.

Stop deforestation and reverse the trends. We don't have long it's time to change.

Look at what's happening worldwide with mass flash flooding, landslides mass die off of fish, animals and birds, massive floating islands of plastic and microscopic pieces of plastic in our seafood!

Without change we are all going to face huge challenges in the near future and we are going to see huge casualties. üòûüòîüò¢

text: More climate change bullshit. There is no such thing as man made climate change. It's just normal sea level fluctuations.  I live in the Great Lakes Basin. Fun Fact: The water levels in the Great Lakes were HIGHER 200 years ago than they are today.  And about 5,000 years ago, the lakes were 23 feet higher. Lake levels have always gone up and down and are currently on another upswing. When I was in school, we went on a field trip. There was a cave that a famous explorer (I forget his name, because I was so young) had used to sleep in about 200 years ago. At that time, the cave was on the edge of the lake. Now, 200 years later, the cave is several hundred yards inland, because the water level dropped.  Water levels are NEVER stable.

text: I don't wanna be the bearer of bad news but most of these islands are ancient volcanic islands that are eroding from rain, wind and waves CONSTANTLY. They keep saying climate change as the cause but I don't buy it. Entire active volcanic islands appear and are washed away over and over before a volcano can build it faster than it's washed away. Ancient volcanoes are no longer building those islands. Every rain, every storm, every breeze, every wave and every tide is washing them away. Look at these islands. All sand. How much of that island disappears in one tropical storm from rain wind and waves? losing an inch off the top doesn't mean sea levels have risen and if you actually look at the amount they say the sea has risen and the amount of land these islands are loosing, That tiny bit of sea level rise alone is no where near responsible. The thing about climate change is that they are all warning about the future and have been doing that for 30 years. They say "rising sea levels" and "could rise as much as" but the current numbers they state of actual rise barely registers so how is it constantly responsible for everything including the common cold all of a sudden.

Fun fact: You can boil sea water and collect the evaporation/steam to create clean drinking water. They could use those long leaves to weave a lid over a pot of boiling water with the edges of the pot lid leafs going to buckets where water will begin to rise up and slide into the buckets.  

Simple way to see this, the water on top of the pot lid when you boil rice or just regular cooking at home. That water came from the steam and it's basically distilled water as if you boiled water from the sink into a pot

I don't blame these islanders, although they're apart of climate change themselves blaming anyone but themselves being apart of the problem because I don't think a lot of them go to standard education.

Just look up simple statistics, it's a google away. The west has lowered their carbon footprint and is still on a downward trend, especially canada. Hell even in  trump's USA (The person everyone loves (joke) ). We're still no longer #1 or 2.

The asian countries stole those titles, and a few european countries. 

It's a little ironic seeing these islanders blaming climate change on the rest of the world too, when they too.. Use modernized items that contribute to climate change.

"Gee I really hate this climate change, but let me go buy a 24 pack of PLASTIC water bottles at the store, and then maybe pick up a PLASTIC milk carton, with some PLASTIC toys for my kids"


A lot of very young people rely on these videos to learn politics I've found out (people below the age of 20).  Look up the real pollution and climate change contributors, it's certainly not the UK, US or Canada. In-fact our parents generation have been working on LOWERING our carbon output before we were even born. Which is why I'm disappointed to see those precious tax paying dollars on "Leaving school protests", where they would've learned this in you know, earth and science class. text:
The Dutch are great at Dikes, building walls and pumping sea water out. Some people say it's only for near land, but they forget that the Dutch have been doing this for hundreds of years. So most of their land is actually below sea level. 
      If you aren't worried about the land being farm able/high in salt, you could speed up the process to within days or months of the walls being completed. 
        
       China is building islands, although how long those islands will last is another question. (Sand thrown on top of coral reefs) However you could do this to create at least temporary buffers. Allowing the waves to be smaller by losing their energy on those landmasses instead of the main island itself. 

Getting engineers and help from other countries espically island cpuntries would be useful as then they'd have people with experience in this. 
       This could include donated materials, ships to transport the materials, builders, and money to fund the construction.  
         If you end up really desperate for this work, you could talk to china about funding it  in exchange for them gaining some land there for some sort of port or something. As it would allow china to gain more power in that part of the world. However, this is risky as they might just take your island over time and kick you all off. So be wary. 


With all this combined, if done right with the right materials, you could complete the project within a year. 

Using that cause way as the foundation for the ocean wall, you might even be able to speed up the project.


I'd assume that getting land that doesn't flood is the main priority for their safety. Then preserving land for them that is futile to provide them with food. 

To slow down the erosion of their sea wall, put up concrete jacks in front of it. This forces the wave to break apart before the wall losing a lot of it's energy. 

Beyond that there's a lot that can be done, but would require more funding. Like large apartments to help with the overpopulation. Hydro farms to increase the food output. (Would require freshwater unless you get hardy salt resistant plants, like lingenberries. Although that particular plant evolved to live on rocks on a coastline. So putting them on the wall or the jacks would be better for those. 

With all this however, you are likely to lose the traditions and culture of the people living there. As the land would be drastically different in the end. However, I think survival takes precedence over culture. 



This is just my thoughts on what could be done to help them. I watched the video, I k ow they don't have a lot of funds for this stuff. So again, things would have to be prioritized. Cost saving ideas would have to be used, like using the causeway as the foundation for the wall, and maybe shooting sand over it to build up land on the side that should be dry. Eventually turning the wall, into a coast.  Again, just my thoughts here.

text: ¬†@War Eagle¬† The Philippines has a total of 7,641 islands, of which only about 2,000 islands are inhabited. If you visit & look beyond Metropolitan Manila, you'll realize how big the Philippines actually is! The Philippines has 81 provinces with 7,641 islands. There are so much land just waiting to be developed. Yes, it's true that the Philippines is still a developing country but it's economy is growing rapidly. The Philippines is a very livable country and it's actually known for its rich biodiversity. It may not be a rich country by your standards but it has so much potential and natural resources. At least, the Philippines has always been known to be welcoming to refugees like the way it did before when the country opened its doors to the oppressed Jewish people when no other country wanted to take them in. The Philippines also took Vietnamese refugees in Palawan and Bataan. Anyway, I wish the people of Kiribati all the best and I hope all the people in the world will take climate change seriously and take some solid actions to properly address the environmental problems the world is facing right now. We only have one planet Earth, it's the only home we have so let's all please take care of it!

text: The Maldives are an exception. The sea levels DID rise as predicted, but the island has been simultaneously increasing in size & lifting up with this growth. Just bc the Maldives got lucky, it doesn't mean that other visibly submerging islands (emphasis: clearly visible, you only need to watch this video) will have the same growing phenomenon. A report on a University of Auckland study revealed "it found eight of the atolls and almost three-quarters of the Maldives islands had grown during the study period, lifting Tuvalu's total land area by 2.9 percent ‚Äì even though sea levels in the country rose at twice the global average.‚Äù And just bc climate always changes does not mean we should allow the unique acceleration of that change. When climate has shifted in the past, it was slow enough for communities (like the Dutch and others) to respond quickly enough to combat the issue. But due to human-caused greenhouse gases, we're seeing a level of climate change that has never been observed in such a short span of time. Nothing like this has ever occured in our history at this speed, and to shrug it off bc you prefer apathy, is lazy and just a way for you to justify your complacency.

text: This is very interesting.  I do believe the climate may be changing.  However, in this film you have also shown other causes for the islands to be sinking.  Sand has a flow, the waves should be washing more sand onto the island to continue to build it up.  Where is the new sand?  You can see the islanders harvesting the coral to build their walls and their homes.  I noticed they are also making cement for building, what is the main ingredient of cement?  Calcium from coral and shells.  They have also over harvested all the sea creatures, which make shells, which also become sand, so sand is being depleted.  The other obvious problem is the coral reefs are dying.  This could be changes in the sea water but it could also be chemicals from all the rubbish scattered across the islands.  These chemicals absolutely kill coral reefs..  Yes, climate change may be the cause of the flooding but I suspect more than 50% of the problem is due to man's influence on the fragile coral environment and also that of healthy sea life.  If the sand isn't being replaced by good coral reefs and crustaceans then you are going to be loosing the sand you already have

text:
For all of the sadness and hand wringing of environmentalists, they never, never discuss, with any seriousness,  the most reasonable, practical and efficient solution to increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere: Nuclear energy. 

Solar and wind sound wonderful but they face numerous problems which in terms of practicality seem insurmountable. 

1)  Individual solar cells produce power at only 0.5 - 0.6 volts per cell. These cells can be connected in series to produce 12 - 24 volt outputs. To increase Power, additional panels must be added. So the voltage of solar panels must be "stepped up" by transformers which incur considerable losses, when compared with a nuclear steam generator which produces power at 22,000 volts!!

2) Nuclear power stations do not require as much land per megawatt as other low-carbon methods of electricity pro-duction. The Arkansas Nuclear One Station requires only 1,100 acres (1.7 square miles) to produce 1,800 megawatts operating at a 90 percent capacity factor. A study by Entergy Arkansas estimates that for modern wind and solar plants operating at the same capacity, they would require 108,000 acres (169 square miles) and 13,320 acres (21 square miles) of land respectively to produce the same amount of power.   wiki

3) Extensive amounts of copper and or cadmium are required to make enough panels to provide power needs in the USA. Additionally, cadmium has serious health risks. 

Go Nuclear!!!!!!!!!

text:
¬†@Christin S.¬† Okay, let me explain the scientific facts again, for all the morons who don't pay attention. Climate change occurs in a global cycle of heating and cooling that has even caused ice ages in the past. However, the last 200 years of atmospheric and sea level data shows marked incongruence with the ice core samples taken in the poles, which shows how climate change normally happens and the way that the global warming we are experiencing in these last centuries is happening way too fast with insanely high CO2 levels,

So no, actually global warming and the corresponding rise in sea levels has not happened this fast in any of the data that science has about the earth's history, and they have a huge amount. 

And considering the difference between low and high tide, maybe those idiots who think soil erosion explains everything should have a look at the SCIENCE on soil erosion. 

Sure, the high rate at which sea level are rising (according to worldwide data on sea levels - which means across the ENTIRE GLOBE) has nothing to do with a drowning island where the sea level is...rising. Oh wait.

text: The sad reality that must be faced by all and that we cannot stop is that these beautiful places are sinking into the rising sea levels. So, the practical, logical thing to do is to stop bringing in so many immigrants from certain other countries but put the people from these sinking Pacific Islands on boats and move them to big dry but still solid land masses, like Australia. They are going to hate being on such a vast dry, barrrn environment like Australia, that is also very cold in the south and fire prone to the east. Compared with the paradise environments they come from, with no water shortage, lush greenery etc. But, at least they won't sinking into the sea. Best places to settle these islanders would be in the warmer, lusher tropical areas of Australia, to the north eg parts of Queensland that has lush tropical forests, tropical fruits etc are are by the sea, as these island people are very much sea people who fish etc to eat. They could work well in such industries in Australia and fit in, adapt OK. Putting them incities or on outback remote vast cattle stations or farming in temperate southen areas or mining in Western Australia in blazing 50 Centigrade heat and little water would kill them off in no time. The best way to help migrants settle into a new land and retain their sanity after so musch stress and upheaval in their lives is to put them into an area that is as close as possible to the sort of environment and what they did in their old land. Eg if they were sea and fishing people, put them near the sea, doing jobs like fishing etc. If they were agricultural types, like farmers, settle them on farming areas. If they were herders from hot dry places eg Middle Eastern people, send them outback to capture snd herd all the wild camels out there, causing havoc, breeding prolifically. These middle Eastern people would be very expert at dealing with camels and useful export and other industries could be set up culling these camel plagues eg capture our nice big fat healthy young camels and export them to the Middle East. Or breed pedigree white "show camels" for their novelty value, to sell to the very affluent types who like these as a status symbol, like we value a Rolls Royce to get around in for some special occasion eg a bride's wedding day transport or for other big celebration calling for great pomp and splendour that some cultures have.Asian people seem to be perfectly at ease in highly congested, polluted, noisy etc  large cities in Asia, be as are many Indians. text:
Over the course of the Earth‚Äôs 4.5-billion-year history, the climate has changed a lot.¬†This is true.¬†But the rapid warming we‚Äôre seeing now can't be explained by natural cycles of warming and cooling.¬†The kind of changes that would normally happen over hundreds of thousands of years are happening in decades.¬†

Global temperatures are now at their highest since records began. In fact, 17 of the 18 warmest years on record have all taken place since 2001.¬†¬†

This much faster warming corresponds with¬†levels of carbon dioxide¬†in the atmosphere, which have been increasing since the industrial revolution. So, when people talk about climate change today, they mean anthropogenic (man-made) climate change. This¬†is¬†the warming of Earth‚Äôs average temperature as a result¬†of human activity, such¬†as burning coal, oil and gas¬†to produce¬†energy¬†to fuel our homes and transport¬†and cutting down trees to¬†produce the food we eat.

Global warming is causing the Earth‚Äôs average surface temperature to increase.¬†This is not only making heatwaves and droughts more likely but it‚Äôs also causing changes to our natural climate systems. These changes are making extreme weather events more likely and more severe. For example, hurricanes and storms are becoming more intense, moving slower and taking longer to die down.¬†¬†

Because of where we are, the UK & Ireland are likely to get more rain and wind as a result of climate change while New York will see more snow.

It's a commonly-held belief that renewable energy is expensive, but¬†this simply isn‚Äôt true! Solar power¬†and onshore wind are the cheapest ways of generating electricity; meaning the energy they produce is cheaper than using nuclear, gas and fossil fuels.¬†¬†

The cost of renewables has fallen faster than anyone could have predicted.¬†And yet the government are still backing dirty fossil fuels. Did you know the UK has the biggest fossil fuel subsidies in the EU? That‚Äôs right, they spend an eye-watering¬†‚Ç¨12bn (¬£10.5bn) a year supporting dirty fossil fuels.
author: D A

text:
Simple chemistry¬†‚Äì When we burn carbon-based materials, carbon dioxide (CO2) is emitted¬†(research beginning in the 1900s).

Basic accounting¬†of what we burn, and therefore how much CO2 we emit¬†(data collection beginning in the 1970s).

Measuring CO2¬†and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and trapped in ice to find they are increasing, with levels higher than anything we've seen in nearly a million years¬†(measurements beginning in the 1950s).

Chemical analysis¬†of the atmospheric CO2 that reveals the increase is coming from burning fossil fuels¬†(research beginning in the 1950s).

Basic physics¬†that shows us that CO2 absorbs heat¬†(research beginning in the 1820s).

Monitoring climate conditions¬†to find that the air, sea and land is warming, as we would expect with rising greenhouse gas emissions; as a response, ice is melting and sea level is rising¬†(research beginning in the 1930s).

Ruling out natural factors¬†that can influence climate like the sun and ocean cycles¬†(research beginning in the 1830s).

Employing computer models¬†to run experiments of natural versus human-influenced simulations of Earth¬†(research beginning in the 1960s).

Consensus among scientists¬†who consider all previous lines of evidence and make their own conclusions¬†(polling beginning in the 1990s).

text: Misleading report.  Several academic papers have shown that even with the variables of sea level rise coral islands are not being overwhelmed.  A major study of 709 atolls in the Pacific and Indian Ocean - including two islands in Kiribati - and published in the Journal WIREs Climate Change in 2018 found that over the past decades no atoll lost land area and 88.6% were either stable or increase in area. No island larger than 10ha has decreased in size.  As with all atolls there are localised effects that arise from unstable coral islands, which are always shifting.  Where there is local erosion of the coast it is largely localised impacts from human disturbance.

text:
The Sea level EVERYWHERE over our FLAT earth is exactly the same height , indisputable.  The scammers who push the lies of a climate issue know this truth very well and they exploit it daily. Up to date, none of these scammers have been able to prove their lies and have been exposed many times for altering climate data to reinforce their lies . Both NOAA and NASA have also been exposed for altering data to fit the alarmist cash making agenda.No one denies that these SAND BASED islands appear to be sinking , for just like Venice, you cannot expect sand or mud to keep still when it is always being submerged on a daily basis.Winds and Tides are the culprit here , just as those same conditions have done for thousands of years , and all these climate alarmist opportunists know this truth so they have exploited these islanders with fake science in order to fool them into thinking the reason is based on climate issues when clearly it is not.
Sand based islands were never a good base to live or build on , this is why we have hundreds  of empty sand based islands all over our earth today. As time is now proving that this island may be in trouble because of its sand based footprint ,  it does NOT mean it will not be here for the next thousand years because NO ONE KNOWS . To think that anyone can prevent mother nature from taking this island is stupidity beyond belief.....Mankind is based on greed  and financial return ,  so to find the money to save this island would be astronomical and the returns would not justify those costs. How naive to think that mankind could ever beat mother nature anyway, and how stupid to think that coral stacked up against a low level wall can somehow  save the island from the sea when the REAL issue is the BASE of the island that is the real problem. This sad issue has been totally exploited (as usual) by the same money grabbing climate scammers , these scammers care nothing about the people living on the island , it always about the profit potential they see in this situation.

text:
It's obvious something else is going on. They have a mainly sandy soil and you see very little grass near the beaches. They have no root structure to help hold sand in place. So it's just washing away. Water is self leveling. If it's raising there it would be raising elsewhere. The answer is to maintain their seawalls and plant salt tolerant grasses. Those coral walls may protect a house from spray from the waves but they do nothing to stop erosion.
   Those floating homes aren't the answer either. It's just spending money foolishly. They live on a low elevation island of sand. Not a volcanic mountainous island. They need to build concrete sea walls and reclaim the sand washing away.

text:
In Florida, it carries a heavy fine, jail time if you destroy mangroves. Why? Because they help with beach erosion and protect the coastline. Yet, people, big companies get away with it to build to an apartment complex or whatever they prefer....money. Why do we not go and help these beautiful, natural islands, people who live off the island....they don't need fuel, they need trees, they need protection to stop erosion, .....

I have watched thousands upon thousands of mangroves torn down for buildings only to be halted due to investor running out of money....well, the sea water runs into their pools, deteriorates the land, pushes sand out and killing species that are more inland, exposes their sprinkler systems.....and insurance pays??? And then I watched for 4+ years out of some govt money and taxpayers, pay to dredge due to oil spill and pump sand back onto the beach so things like this wouldn't occur.
author: BRANDY D

text:
This documentary made me really sad- as odd as it is, my grandfather was wounded fighting the Japanese on Tarawa in World War II, and because of what happened on this apparently tiny bit of beautiful island- my grandfather was sent back to the states long enough to impregnate my grandmother before getting sent back to fight on Okinawa, where he unfortunately lost most of his limbs to Japanese machineguns and essentially wouldn‚Äôt make it much longer after the war.
It saddens me to know that this island I‚Äôve always been told stories of and have been curious about visiting is in this bad of shape. :‚Äô(

Ohhh my heart..., I hope my government (Indonesia) could see this video, and try to help Kiribati or any Pacific Countries that are facing the same problems, or if it possible, invite and provide you guys a place in Papua, because the land is huge but still have less people. You guys are islanders just like us, and we need to stick together. Beside the Pacific Islander culture and Eastern Indonesian are identic.

Idk if you guys will be happy or not moving to overseas. Speaking of migrating, while you guys still thinking about it, and wanting to stay longer in Kiribati, maybe these tips could help:
1. Plant more mangroves to prevent the abrasion alongshore to defend the land from eroding, instead of building a sea wall coz it just wasting time. Beside you'll kill the fish's house. Coz Fish lives in the reefs or corals. So, by destroying them you'll lose the fish gradually. By the way, if the coral or reef become bigger, they could catch sand or any solid material, so by letting them grow, you could gain more island or more area in the future I think.

2. DO NOT over-extracting your ground water (if you guys have) coz it leads to the land sinking like what my capital Jakarta is having now.

3. The desalination plant is a good short term program to solve the fresh water crisis, but if it possible, do more environmental engineering.

4. Do Planting more various types of plants in the bigger mass area. You guys could try Banyan tree that is believed could gather the ground water. Or many more types of staple food plants.

text: I see people all the way around the equator exploiting their natural habitats in order to get money. The natives don't need this dependency on money but they think they do. We must introduce a complete guide to independent and green living on Kiribati and everywhere in the world. When you live on Kiribati for example what the environmentalists are already doing when they are planting Mangrows they are helping the eco system to adapt to the rising ocean levels and this is already a fantastic step to make. I am very grateful that they are doing that. All natives need to plant Mangrows along the coast. Another step is to Not breed animals and Not slaughter animals anymore. The natives and every human can live fully whole food vegan. Whole plant food is the best for our health. People must question their old traditions and habits or any type of exploitation for money. Don't cook plants and don't cook palm sugar water. Don't even engage into a trade market of any kind. Stay at home with your precious resources and keep the resources whole. Eat the plants and drink the juices fresh every day. Trade work locally and trade plants locally. Another very important step is to do composting of all biodegradable materials including animal dung and human dung this is vitally important for the planet and our our health and must be implemented everywhere on the planet. We need to bring decomposed biomass material back into the eco system and the soil for healthy plants to grow and for our own nutrition. In the western world they have been taking nutrients away from the soil now for over 100 years. Rudolf Steiner warned us about the soil depletion but nobody listened to him. Now the food they grow is empty of nutrients. What we take we have to put back into the land. People need to learn to use bucket toilets which work very well and they are very clean with compost and plant clippings that fall off as a side product from trimming hedges, mowing lawns, cutting food plants etc. It is helpful to get mulch processing tools that create an easy to work with pulp or finely shredded plant material for use in the toilet buckets and also for cleaning the seats and buckets with mulch and ocean water this works very well No soap is even necessary. There are some plants that have natural saponins (which are soap elements) in them which also grow in tropical regions and which work the best fresh for washing hair and body for animals and humans. Solar energy can be stored in batteries fed with solar roofs to create self sustainable electricity for garden tools and computers etc. The toilet buckets can always be emptied into large compost areas designated for decomposing biomass materials. We use large trash containers which hold like 40 gallons of biomass. We drilled holes into the bottom for scavenger insects to get into it and worms. We also drilled some holes on the side and also into the lid for rainwater to get in so that the biomass stays hydrated for the worms and insects. The scavenger insects will decompose the dung compost quickly within just a few weeks into fertile Earth soil which then can be emptied into an open area from where it can be utilized for planting food plants again. You can create a completely sustainable system where money is not even necessary anymore. You can create your own paradise.

text: What will it take for the rest of the world to know that Kiribati are NOT A SOUTH PACIFIC ISLANDS?  Kiribati is geographically a north western pacific in the Micronesian island group; including the Republic of Belau, the Marshalls, Nauru and the Federated States of Micronesia.  Guam and the Northern Marianas are also NORTH PACIFIC but early "invasion" and colonization separated these islands.  They were originally separated by water only but celestial navigators among some islands held a very thin fabric of unity until the "big sails" came (and the priests and missionaries).

text: Oof. So the bulk of this is not sea level rise but land subsidence, older coral atolls that are at the end of their life cycle begin to sink, it's just what they do. They aren't seeing more sea level rise due to climate change than anyone else, that's impossible sea level rise is global and there are a lot of other low lying areas that would be effected first. Of course, climate change exacerbates and accelerates this problem, as it does flooding everywhere from the netherlands to miami. But Kiribati in particular, and anyone living on a subsiding coral atoll, will have to move eventually either way.

text: ¬†@C K¬† The climate change you are describing is interglacial climate change. This happens when temperatures increase and then decrease between glacial periods (or "ice ages") and is natural, yes. However, it is undeniable that humans, through the use of fossil fuels and machinery that emits greenhouse gases, have manually thickened the ozone layer are trapping more heat from the sun on the planet. This is man-made climate change: it IS real, it IS leading to sea level change in areas such as Kiribati and it IS preventable. And the fact that it continues to be worsened by uneducated and uncaring people is definitely saddening.

text: Kiribati is made up of 33 islands/atolls and 12 are uninhabited. It happens. With or without modern technology, climate and sea levels have always been changing and have made many previously inhabited island uninhabitable. They will simply have to find somewhere else to live unless you're saying they're going to kill themselves or something. Ancient Polynesians left islands all the time to go to other ones. This is one atoll that will join the list of uninhabitable atolls. That's nature and it's no one else's fault. There will also be atolls/islands that crop up/become inhabitable again too. Same can be said for people who live in Venice, Miami, New Orleans, etc. Eventually there will be a day those places are uninhabitable. People used to live in Pompeii, too. You just move or die. That's life.

author: J. Mendana

text:
I hear what you are saying. At least as much as possible from an outsider's perspective, I understand how your sense of identity, your way of life, and your cultural pride connect you to your island home.

And although empathy for any among us is sufficient cause for change; for our transition into a species that lives harmoniously with its environment, an even deeper cause is that what affects a part of us ultimately affects the whole of us.

 I wish to add however, that I believe you cannot possibly lose who you are by losing your land, or by losing any material thing, or by a change in your perceived sense of identity. You are greater than that by unfathomable orders of magnitude.

That is the greatness in you. That is the greatness in all of us. And that is the greatness of spirit that will triumph over shortsighted human fear, greed, and perceived isolation so that we can see who we really are.

We are harmony, peace, and contentment incarnate already. Only our temporal forms need time to realize it.

text:
Everyone thinks global warming is the main cause of the rising sea level. Yet many seem to ignore the consequences of extreme urbanization and land expansion into the sea along coastal cities. 
(1) Urban communities that have paved roads, drainage and expansion covering all its environment make it difficult for the land to soak and trap rain water. Thus, almost all the rain water flood into the creeks, rivers overflowing into swamps, lakes, spilling more than its normal volume of water into the sea. When that happens, mud and debris end up along the river banks and lakes forcing water further out towards the other end.
(2) When a large swampy land or an area that contains a body of water is being filled with hard rocks and soil to create land space, the amount of water in that area is being pushed out causing a rise in the sea level in flat coastlines.
We don't necessarily need a scientific research to verify that. Any average person can understand this natural law of cause and effect.
Affluent industrialized cities should stop the expansion of land along the seashores. The more water you push out from your end, some tiny islands in the Pacific ocean are losing their homes.

text: The nearest plausible solution may read like this: this country looks like a seriously stunning tourist destination. If the government can allow for heavy investment in resorts, it may afford to pay for the Engineering works needed to salvage the sinking islands/atolls. If in Dubai, and Coast of Lagos Nigeria, completely new Islands could be created in the sea, then its no doubt, even Kiribati's islands can be rebuilt. There is enough sand and coral in that sea to help them raise the levels of the whole island by at least 3-4 metres. The world can help them. Heavy precast concrete barriers/reefs followed by sand-filling, demolition of the houses and building them on the new higher ground, and finally, placing sea level monitoring systems both near and deeper in the sea for early warning, Island sinking monitoring systems etc can be done to save the Paradise even as we struggle to make hydrogen and oxygen replace hydrocarbon fuels. Invest in their tourism potential, invest in fishing, etc. Those should be worth at least a few billion dollars.

text:
Yes, but western nations emit far more per capita, and as developed nations, they also have the economic strength to more easily transition to renewable and cleaner resources. The issue being raised here is that they are the best poised to make a much needed transition, yet they're not (at least not nearly quick enough).

text:
The seas have been rising at the same rate for 300 years.

What they need to do is dredge the sea floor for sand and use that to build up the land. IF they move the sand from the edge of the sea at low tide they could build a larger area to keep the sea away.

Just imagine IF they went to the edge at low time, walked a short distance with a float barge and loaded it up. Then when high tide came in, they could float it to a few feet from their homes and dump it. A simple float could hold several cubic yards of soil, then dump it in a pile. In a single year, they could bring 1000 cubic¬†yard of soil to the edge of their home. IF the that wall is¬†two yard¬†tall,¬†that would be an addition 500¬†square yards of¬†land around their home to protect them from sea rise.

A wall half a yard wide at the top and angling outwards could easily be 500 foot long and would protect them for the next century. Considering that the island has approximately 2.6 million feet, and one family can do 500 feet in a year if they choose to, IF they have 500 families, they will only need ten years to give them a century of protection.

text: Whether the sea is rising or the island sinking, it is irresponsible to the max to throw up our hands and, say, 'it is not our fault.' , and do nothing. We have damaged the earth severely, and there is a lot that can be done to improve matters. Rivers all over the world are silted to the point of extinction, forests are disappearing by wild fires and over exploitation. Chemicals are used in agriculture which cause gigantic health problems, and jet aircraft, ever increasing, are demolishing the balance and stability of the entire atmospheric blanket. We can do a lot to improve matters, but first we have to admit that we have caused much of the problem. It is grossly irresponsible to pretend it is sunspots or cosmic rays, or natural cycles, when it is patently obvious that we are very likely the main driver of the terrible weather events happening ever more frequently. The planet is dying of consumption. The remedy is to consume less for a start.

text:
¬†@hhhk20¬† What exactly about them is backwards, may I ask? 
It can't be their poverty, as being located on an isolated network of islands largely barren of natural resources will do that to any people.
Hard to argue it's their cultural heritage, as they're part of the Austronesian cultural family, the most successful and dispersed seafaring people in human history.
You could argue it's their religion, but as they're nearly all Christian, it would be a tough argument to sell to Americans and other westerners.
And it definitely can't be their Mangrove forestation strategy, as that is one of the most cost-efficient ways to prevent soil erosion.

And why can't they be helped? Even if their islands sink, there's land in Fiji for them and countless countries with more than enough room for their relatively small population. In the meantime, there's plenty of charity work and programs that could work wonders for reducing poverty and injecting some capital into the economy there.

text:
Global Warming BS.   Sea levels are not rising.  

There is zero evidence for the claim that Kiribati is sinking, but there is plenty of evidence for the opposite - that such low-lying atoll islands are not sinking, but growing.

Virginie K. E. Duvat, of the Institut du Littoral et de l'Environnement, University of la Rochelle, France states:

A reanalysis of available data, which cover 30 Pacific and Indian Ocean atolls including 709 islands, reveals that no atoll lost land area and that 88.6% of islands were either stable or increased in area, while only 11.4% contracted...

Over the recent past, 29 atolls exhibited a stable land area, while one (South Tarawa, Kiribati) increased in size

This confirms earlier studies:

Professor Paul Kench and Dr Arthur Webb studied 27 atoll islands in the central Pacific over a period of up to 60 years. They said:  "Results show that 86% of islands remained stable (43%) or increased in area (43%) over the timeframe of analysis."

text: It is a misconception that the ocean level is rising. It hasn't changed, regardless of graphs. If levels are "rising" at Puerto Ric's beaches, then they would be rising around the world. They aren't. They are at the same level they have been for the last 40 years (I live on the coast and it would be seen). Like the Cliffs of Dover and the Northern European WW2 shore gunnery embankments falling into the sea, erosion of soft soil by way of tidal action is responsible for loss of beaches. Since the advent of extremely accurate digital measuring devices in the early '90s, it is proven that sea levels have not risen since '93, in direct contradiction to environmentalists' claims. If you put a large chunk of ice in a bucket of water and let it melts, the water level in the bucket doesn't change. So, the issue isn't global warming. The climate has been changing second to second since the birth of Earth's atmosphere, 4.5B years ago. The climate changes from warm to cold and back again like a pendulum, and will continue to do so, long after humanity is gone. As an example, both poles have been either temperate or tropical forests, a hundred times over, each forestation episode lasting from 1,000 to 100,000 years and then back to ice. Proof is in the fossil record from ground corings (ferns and palms in both poles). This occurs on average, every 20M to 25M years, through a combination of planetary and solar conditions. People should never build in a flood plain or tidal zone. That is courting disaster. For the apparent rise in water levels here, this island is located, like many others, on active tectonic fault lines. Plates rise and sink. This one is sinking. We have been in a warming period for the last 5,000 years, since the area around the pyramids was much more green then, than it is today. For the poles to be forested, the average planetary temperature would normally be 20'Centigrade warmer than it is today. The primate evolutionary tree wasn't even around during the last forestation period, so how is it that "scientists" who should know alot better, claim that we are responsible? Is the planet warming? Yes. Is it a normal and regular occurance? Yes. Will it get cold again? Yes. It's the pendulum effect. It happens in an active, living atmosphere with interactive global macro weather patterns. Think for yourselves and don't jump onto the politicized and hysterics laden environment bandwagon (someone is making alot of money off peoples' ignorance and hysteria).

author: gecsus

text:
¬†@J D¬†N Not one model has ever produced an accurate prediction. So I call BS.  The worst greenhouse gasses do not include CO2.  Methane, yes. CO2, no.  It is less than .06% of the atmosphere.
By the way... I am against Big Oil, but natural gas is abundant and less of a problem.  We do need an energy source that is both efficient and economical and most of the real contenders have been suppressed. On this, we probably agree, but it still doesn't make the science of climate change accurate, real or reliable.  Also, unless the data is weighted, temperature does not follow the production of CO2 in the atmosphere. The data clearly indicates some of the coldest temperature periods were when CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere were at their highest before man was even contributing any measurable amount of CO2. Go look it up.

The human race is also dependant upon economics as well as resources.  Remove economics by destruction and overreaction and then produce nothing because there are no consumers or production and the human race declines significantly as will the standard of living worldwide.

text:
If you finance using the techniques to preserve seaice it'd be greatly appreciated.

With levees and artificial shoals to trap  sand and allow the outer reef to grow protected.

It all boils down to dealing with Arctic seaice, HEAT GAINED in the 2007 retreat was 95,000-Twh over average.

Closing all Steam-Age power plants 250Mwh and above is a one-time save of 36,000-Twh in emitted wasteheat.

That's 2‚Ä¢1/2-times too little to balance the gain vs the loss compared to the 1980-2000 average ice extent.

Losing the seaice is "game-over" on RUNAWAY GREENHOUSING in the Arctic, this is what brings the extremes in weather vs assuming it'd get tropical for midwest farmers, eh?

Also, the Arctic Ocean is at the aragonite saturation point, all that a local marine biologist saw flying over the newly opened water were jellyfish, millions of them.

There is no fishery there as it becomes open water, this zone expands south, in 60yrs the upper half of the Bering Sea will have few pteropods, there's no replacement species.

The serious 'Last Hurrah' for it all, to me, for what humanity needs to do asap: 

Install a weir dam at St. Lawrence Is. and polder north the entire Chukchi Sea to prevent wave damage and stratify the water to refreeze the bottom creating a year-round seaice refuge.

ALL shipping confined within 3-4km of shore, ZERO cross-ocean traffic, this uses Dutch ships, materials and methods to create polders, shoals & levees. 

The task submerged "atolls" encircling the large subsea¬†methane vents down at 150m/490ft, this uses the bubble flow to pull in colder bottom water which refreezes them.

It all confines the freshwater runoff and most of all limits early melting from shore out to-sea in spring.

This reduces the 5-Amazons of warmer, fresher water to 1/100th of what it is that's melting the seaice from below.

Fresher water freezes at a higher temperature so true seaice isn't formed at the surface on freezeup, it needs -2C/28.4F for seaice to last over ONE season.

This intends to prevent the Siberian jetstream from turning north and can be modelled.

The N.Pacific is too warm and heats the airmass from below, so, with The Blob in the Gulf of AK it drives the jetstream pattern north, needs to change back closer to Holocene paths.

So, the warmth sends rain to Anchorage in December and frozen oranges to Florida the routine now, started early this fall, eh?

As that air cools it now gets to low latitudes ONLY over land to balance equatorial overheating, same for Eurasia.

The concept has 36,000 views on a seaice forum and zero actions upon it.

It's the only geographic location on Earth with the ability to alter the Anthropocene jetstream paths back into N.America instead of going north.

I can't order it done, the people in the poop deck party think everything's fine with lifeboats already in the water ...

In any case, it's the ONLY sane try to alter things not dependent upon emissions to overcome those effects enough to give MIDWEST FARMERS a break, else, expect a repeat of this past year or worse, eh?

text: exactly.   These islands are sand atols that form over undersea coral.   Sand either accumulates or washes away, just like the dunes in the desert or sandbars in a riverbed.  You can't measure sea levels on such islands.  There is no bedrock,  only shifting sand.  When undersea volcanos create new islands the displaced water causes sea levels to rise and this in turn accelerates erosion of low lying atols. It's a never ending cycle of change and renewal.

text:
¬†@isawondfl1¬†
I do not know you personally and I do not know where you stand on the validity of climate change, but I wished to clear up some of the misunderstandings anyone coming across your post may have. 
 "...earthquakes move the tectonic plates..." this is a misappropriation of cause and effect, earthquakes do not cause the movement of tectonic plates but rather are an effect of the shifting and grinding of those plates.
"...islands to sink due to old and dead coral..." as one of numerous processes and effects of the larger phenomenon of climate change, increasing acidification of ocean water causes marine ecosystems, specifically ones in which coral reefs ought to prosper,  to be increasingly uninhabitable for those sea life and leading to growing number of dying coral reefs. 
Furthermore, the displacement between the sea level and elevation of those atolls are also affected by growing rates of erosion as the foundation of many pacific ocean islands are degrading due to those processes of climate change.
And I'm not too sure on how much effect  general seismic activity has on marine ecosystems, so I sincerely doubt that islands are sinking due to earthquakes and not erosion and rising sea level.

text:
¬†@Perry James Allen¬† There are actually places where we can se the sea water rice, in Norway, but the land will after a while start rise again. Worldwide, an annual increase in sea level of 3 mm has been measured. Melting water and sea temperature rise contribute about as much to sea level rise.
There are several factors that can also increase sea level, but they have a greater local impact.
Fresh water occupies a larger volume than salt water. In places where the sea receives increased fresh water content, this could lead to higher sea levels locally.
If climate change changes ocean currents, it also matters. A new distribution of hot and cold water will change the sea level locally in the places affected by this.
The sea is not flat, although it may look like this. It is due to the gravitational force. Mass attracts mass also horizontally. The greater the mass, the greater the attraction. Large land masses attract more water than smaller land masses do.
This means that there will be consequences for the sea level locally if large ice masses on the mainland melt away. For example, when the ice over Greenland is reduced, it reduces the gravitational force so that Greenland gets less attraction on the surrounding water. The meltwater will therefore not flood the Greenland coastline. On the contrary. The sea level around Greenland may fall, Greenland's land masses will rise, even what today is under water will rise above, due to the heaviness of today's ice masses melting, and then the oceans of the world will rise, and have already startet!

text:
¬†@Arf Gulp¬† 
First off, using "averages" is a bad habit that people have to break, it doesn't help to look at averages which can be offset by outliers and exceptions.

Your numbers seem to be lacking allot of information.
7.2tonnes of CO2 per person... is that per year? or per lifespan?
And is that another average?
Shouldn't you be counting totals, not averages?

Totals are the bottom line.
And in 2017 "China was the biggest emitter of carbon dioxide; the country accounted for around 27.2 percent of global CO2 emissions that year."
Because of China's massive population it's average CO2 per person is lowered because the vast majority of them live in poverty and can't even afford to produce much CO2.
So NO China hasn't really done it's part, only because of the fact that it's citizens live in squalor does it look good in some interpretations of statistics.

But the bottom line is, China produces the most CO2 and that's the Bottom Line because the blame doesn't land on all the millions of Chinese citizens as individuals but on the state as a whole.
Of course some individuals are more responsible than most.

Personally, I think all those powerful nations should perhaps do more, but my perspective is a Native Oceanic Perspective and I'm sick and tired of seeing our seas fall prey to foreign powers.
Worst of all at the moment is China because they are nearby and their pollution directly affects our climate here in Oceania.

text: Indoctrinating, and brainwashing even the poorest of the inhabitants of the earth.  Very sad.  Global temperatures rise and fall historically.  There's nothing anyone can do about it.  If tide, and waterlines change, then people move to other areas.  Just like they moved their homes to the shorelines in the past as water receded, they can move their homes back from the water, or move to higher ground, or other islands.  Carbon dioxide is a natural, yet minuscule part of our atmosphere.  Less than 1%.  The oceans, the earth's core, and the sun control global temperatures more than anything man could do.  Man is NOT causing global temperatures to change, nor can he if he tried.  We don't control the earth.   Get over it.

Spot on. I‚Äôve always been suspicious regarding global warming and decided at my age (48 yo) to make a Bachelor in environmental science, just to educate myself. 

What I‚Äôm finding is that the global warming hysteria is a coverup to a way more seriously problems we are facing in the world, The pollution. It‚Äôs already killing lots of people, especially in the third world when they produce our cheep products, or ‚Äútaking care‚Äù our electric waste. This list can go on forever. 

But this is very sensitive topic, as this is the result from this new modern religion (if I may say so jokingly) called ‚ÄúGlobal Economical Growth‚Äù. Mass consumption is the key to make few people filthy rich, while our Mother Earth is paying the price. 

Imagine if media could talk as much about toxic rivers and ground water due to industry, pesticides in our food, etc like they do about global warming. That will never happen! To much money are involved. 

This year I promote to everyone I know, to reduce buying Christmas gifts to a minimum, and think twice before buying cheap crappy electronics.

text: Not one discussion about PROOF this is due to 'Climate Change'. Who is doing subsidance testing? Who has placed GPS-based altimeters to validate 'no land-shift' is taking place? The TOTAL LIE of 'the oceans are rising' is, well, just that, a lie...if the oceans were rising, WORLD OCEAN LEVELS would rise...and if world ocean levels rose, you KNOW that every military naval base in the world would have pier and harbor issues...and that large shipping canals (Suez, Panama, etc.) would have catastrophe immediately! There is nothing to suggest that any realistic changes are happening at these places...but we also know that islands form, and islands sink, and islands shift...so, when you want to discuss 'altimeter changes' of the island, great, let's talk. When you want to talk about liquifaction, subsiance, deforestation (by the locals), coastal shelf sand build-up...ok...let's talk....but stop with 'Sea Level Rise by Climate Change'...because until we see this effect impacting the Panama Canal, or Pearl Harbor, it's all just smoke-and-mirrors for the fools who couldn't make it through an Engineering Degree in College.

text: ¬†@Dororthy Crutison¬† I don't know if you are just trolling this video, but regardless, Western countries are responsible for the acceleration of climate change. To your point, yes, are living in an interglacial period which follows a natural progression of warming and cooling. However, without the impact of human industry (and other high-carbon activities), we would likely barely notice Earth processes (like sea-level rise) because the impact would be so minimal. Of course, there have always been storms, and will always be storms, but human activity has been proven time and time again to have a dramatic affect on the natural world. With that said, I think a lot of people have trouble grasping this concept because it seems impossible for our daily choices to have such a large impact. That is partly true.. with a few major caveats... I will always advocate strongly for more environmentally conscious choices, but individual carbon footprints are not most prominent producer of climate change--for that, we look to industry. This is why we need to encourage our government to prioritize climate change--this is undoubtably the biggest threat to the human population.

text:
You can say that climate change is INDEED to blame but you can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs anything to do with humans. I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôve attributed some to it but things like this have happened MANY times over the course of the history of earth. Plate tectonics, land erosion, and the climate changing is how this world was formed and it‚Äôs been doing it for BILLIONS of years. We‚Äôve seen at least five ice ages that lasted millions of years. What was the cause for them retreating back then? Woolly Mammoth farts? 
And even if America went TOTALLY off the grid tomorrow it would do NOTHING! Besides, America already LEADS the world in reducing our carbon footprint. In the past five years we‚Äôve reduced carbon emissions by some 758 million metric tons while China has increased by 3 BILLION tons and India by over 1 BILLION tons in that same time. Even Canada has INCREASED their carbon footprint in that time. So, if you ask me IF it is indeed caused by man then get your life jackets on now. There‚Äôs nothing we can do about it.

text:
Sea level is relative and changes are meaningless unless put into context. Pacific Coral Atolls are extinct oceanic volcanoes which formed above Mantle plumes. The plumes are effectively stationary and the oceanic plate moves over the top of them. This is why chains of islands are formed. The plume pushes the oceanic crust upwards and a volcano develops. With plate movement  the volcano is moved physically away from the plume which makes the volcano extinct and the sea begins to erode it. At the same time because the oceanic crust of which it is part cools, the eroding
volcano sinks. Corals seed themselves on the eroding volcano and grow up towards the light.  It then becomes a race between the coral growing and the atoll sinking. In the end the atoll wins and sink below the waves, eventually become a guyot. The cause is thermal subsidence and nothing whatsoever to do with  changes in sea level due to climate change, its basic erosion .

Secondly there is absolutely nothing to gain from denying climate change, because if it is true then the worst outcome is that we will all be hugely and horribly effected by it (Yes Europe and the US too). But if we take action now then most of the effects can be put to a stop/reduced. Please please please do your research before spreading such damaging and naive stories. All climate activists want to do is take down the fossil fuel and other (about 100) corporations that produce some 70% of the world's carbon emissions and turn to eco friendly/low greenhouse gas/sustainable alternatives. This is completely doable and will actually help improve the quality of life for people all over the world (I believe in Germany last year 30,000 people died from air pollution caused by smog from cars (improved public transportation and encouraged local community growth is a beautiful alternative to the capitalist idea that every adult individual needs a car). author: Joseph W

text:
¬†@Joseph W¬† Climate change is an umbrella-term for the several processes and phenomenon of changes in the planet's global weather averages, including erosion, ocean acidification, rising sea level, heavier and unsustainable rainfall, longer droughts, glaciation and last but not least the rise of global averages of temperature, and many more.

Many of the major geographic processes are indeed human-aided, as a result of humans' tremendous ability to affect our environment. Agriculture is literally the changing and domestication of animals and plants and land to suit the needs of food and water security. Why can't climate change be in some manner, caused or at least accelerated by human action?

And I would agree with you, that climate change is not the fault of individuals like you or I or anyone else's direct actions.
Rather, and this has been the case for many years, that it is the fault of entrenched institutions and large corporate businesses maintaining a status quo that benefits them and stockholders in the short-term but fails to conserve the human environment.

So, please, don't go around straight up calling ideas or well-documented geographic processes lies b/c they don't fit a narrative? 

As for whether or not it was intelligent of the people to settle on a island, well that's kind of a self-centered and unnuanced way to look at it. Those islands are some persons' homes, with families and past childhoods, so it seems very disrespectful and unbecoming to just denigrate some person's ancestors just b/c they settled somewhere that may not be there hundreds to thousands of years later.
I suppose a good analogy, would be a cattle ranching family has had an estate with good grazing and open spaces to their family for generations only to be wiped away from a flash flood, just because the ranch was settled on a flood plain. 

Furthermore, in the wake of seemingly obstinate industrial countries unwilling to change their policies, pacific islands and small nation-states are forced to double down on adapting to a sadly inevitable force of rapid change. These countries are struggling to adapt to overcome these challenges. The most effective action we can do may be pushing our industrial governments to take action.
