text:
Yeah, back when the tectonic plates were positioned and stretched differently, a lot of places we think of as solid ground were at different elevations. The North American plate, for instance, had a great big sea in the middle of it, which has made for a lot of nice and otherwise irretrievable marine fossil discoveries.


What also helped is that back in the glory days of the Megalodon, global temperatures were higher, which melted the ice caps and raised sea levels quite a bit. It was only after the waters started cooling that the cold-blooded sharks that we love went extinct.


The continents may have shifted, but we can still see part of this play out as current events unfold. With temperatures rising, the ice caps are melting and the oceans are expanding due to their rise in temperatures (the hotter something is, the more space it takes up, and with something as gargantuan as the ocean, it adds up, if only in feet and inches).


The issue now though is that we're making that change happen way faster than normal. Something that normally takes thousands of years (such as the glacial retreat, melt, and sea level rise of the last ice age) now is being done in decades. The kicker is, it's not even Milankovitch cycles driving it this time, it's just atmospheric absorption of solar energy and the lowering of Earth's surface albedo, both of which cause the Sun to heat the Earth more.


In summary, our issue isn't climate change, it's climate change's erratic variation from the path it should be going on, which as a species reliant on stability to plan literally everything, doesn't work so well for us. :)

Finally, science. Simple science. Water expands when it increases in temperature. Applying that worldwide, average ocean temperature is increasing but due to deep water cold currents Europe, including Venice, aren‚Äôt seeing ocean temperature rise yet due to these cold water currents. Ice melt contribution is minimal compared to physical temperature driven column expansion. Their oceans have risen as much as 0.8 meters, largely due to climate change. text:
The ocean levels are not rising the beaches are disappearing and the islands are sinking. Sand dredging is the scraping and removal of sand and sediment on the ocean floor creating vast voids. As we all have experienced when walking or digging on a beach nature wastes no time filling in these voids. So imagine huge empty spaces, millions of tons of sand removed each year with nature desperately and indiscriminately filling these voids from whatever deposits of sand are available, sand that nature can move in coordination with its natural flow thus sand that can flow from high to low. Sand dredging is one of the most profitable industries in the world as sand is a freely available resource. Sand is being relocated to build artificial islands for wealthy nations, it is used of concrete which is the primary building material of our western cultures, it is used in making all computer chips, fluorescent lights, television screens, fiberglass, glass used in automotive industry, the food industry etc. etc. To blame this on climate change or global warming is an incomplete or inaccurate suggestion. 

I've watched a few documentaries from this channel now and have been very impressed with their content so to watch this one i have to question its motives. These are made by highly intelligent people with great resources so to miss the mark so drastically i wonder, should this be considered propaganda? The creators clearly did not explore the causes of these events, instead ran with the climate change narrative, and for the amount of times they blamed climate change they never once offered any explanation as to what specifically about climate change is doing this. I urge people to watch these videos (and all videos) with caution and to think critically about the information, don't take it for granted as being factual based on production value. Research for yourself the information rather than giving up 45minutes of your time and attention to incomplete possibly deceitful documentaries. Sand dredging... look it up. Check out the documentary Sand Wars. Good luck

text: The ocean rose 120 meters 15000 years ago.  It is not a coincidence that so many of these atolls lie just above present sea level.  Without people, coral grew up with sea level.  Storms brought sand and debris over the coral and filled in, building the islands up.  When people moved in, they cleared and smoothed the land and built roads and buildings.  Now when the coral tries to grow, they move it and their pollution kills it.  And the storm debris gets cleared off the roads and the land.  It isn't just sea level rise, it is the people living there too.  Remove them and the islands will keep up with sea level naturally.  That is simple.  After the next typhoon evacuation, don't come back.
author: Didivs Ivlianvs

text: While it is sad that their land is being washed away, there is no ONE reason that it is occuring. They cannot place ALL of the blame on Western countries. I am sure that they themselves import goods from Western countries. They, too, are adding to pollution with vehicles and plastics, etc. Plates move, rise, and sink, as do islands and atolls with them. They always have and they always will. Ocean currents and the seas change, they always have and they always will. With their high population growth, they demand more and more resources to survive, more land to live on, and they have dessicated many of the mangrove groves on their atoll of which the roots helped slow the erosion leading to the atoll being eaten away by the sea at a faster pace. They are removing large amounts of coral around the atoll which would house fish and that affects their food sources. It is much easier to have someone, anyone, else to place sole blame on for these issues than it is to accept that things are much as they have always been, all things will eventually pass away, and that they themselves have also contributed to their predicament. If you build your home on sand, in the middle of the ocean, it will eventually be washed away. That is the nature of nature, as it were.
author: Shara

text: I thought that dude that invented the internet said that by 2012 all polar bears would be extinct due to drowning and Florida and coastal cities in the US would destroyed by the sea, because of global ice melt? This video is prime example of propaganda. This is what happens when a group of people decide to move to  an "island" (not really an island, but a sand bar) and natural weather changes happen and force them to either be swallowed by the ocean or to move to higher ground. How long did they say these "islands" have been here? What this should teach people is never build your house on a sand bar otherwise it will eventually get destroyed. Just like how people shouldn't sit their houses on a riverbank that will eventually flood or erode away leaving you with a flooded house or a big eroded hole. I guess you can blame "climate change" on that, instead of not having the sense to avoid that situation all together. I guess stupid people that refuse to take accountability, only have "climate change" to blame for their stupidity.

text: Somewhat true. Banaban Islanders were relocated to Rabi by the British so that they could mine the island of it's phosphate deposits resulting in the devastation of the Island. They were promised housing and adequate food on Rabi as a form of compensation for their endeavour however when they arrived they found only tents and food enough to last 2 weeks just before the start of Fiji's notorious typhoon season. Many died the first few months and many Banabans today still feel betrayed by both the British and Kiribati. Some Banabans do not like being called iKiribati for this very reason.

text: ¬†@TM 686¬† Apart from Rabi there is also the pending land lease of Natoavatu. However many local Fijians in the surrounding areas have doubts of Kiribati people being able to thrive as it is not in their culture due to living on atolls. It's common knowledge that a Kiribati provider is a fisherman and not a farmer but people tend to forget that this is not the first time Kiribati people had to exodus from their home. There are also Kiribati people in Solomon Islands primarily in Gizo province who were moved there due to overpopulation in the Southern Islands. If the Kiribatese were to move form their home this would surely not be their first time. They are a quiet people, very reserved and content and rarely if ever cause trouble in the countries they emigrate to.

text:
All of you who keep saying, pump the sand up to rebuild the island. Build new islands, build walls. You clearly didn‚Äôt listen to the whole video closely. THEY ARE POOR!!! They can barely afford a hand pump to draw fresh water. The country as a whole makes about $200 million per year. Island creation costs billions. The Dutch, Chinese, people of Brunei, Kuwait, these are all reasonably wealth to fantastically wealthy countries. They have people in each of these countries that make more individually than this entire country!! Wake up! Come up with REAL and possible ideas. Think of it as spending your own money, THEN what will you do? 
    There IS no sand in the areas where the erosion is removing the sand the people lived on. There are other areas where the sand is building up but not such that you can live on it because it barely, if at all, clears the surface of the ocean. The ocean here is not calm and protected. It is wide open and so there is very little potential to make islands at all, even if there were no limits to the amount of money available. 

     I believe there is climate change and global warming. If we didn‚Äôt exist on this earth, the global warming and climate change would still happen. Most likely at a different, slower, rate. We may have accelerated the issue for sure, but it really isn‚Äôt possible to accurately determine how much faster. The thing that gets smaller mention, but is likely the largest issue is the ocean currents have changed in this area. This creates more erosion and also has created the heavier seas. This is something that could have happened regardless of global warming. Ocean currents are constantly changing.  
    With all this said I cannot think of an answer. I am sure the mangrove planting will help save, and even restore the islands to a degree. They need water ABOVE their roots to survive though so there is an equilibrium point that may or may not work. Gotta try though. Eventually the growth will become so thick that it will be hard to access the ocean through the mangroves. There is always a trade off. 
     I do wish the people the best of health and luck. It is a touchy subject, but, maybe have smaller families with 1 or 2 children for a few decades to slow the increasing demand  for more land when the land is disappearing. This should be starkly obvious to the least educated there even. The government could communicate the fact that the country has less and less land for the people to live on. The population can not afford to double in the next 20 years. Probably not even the next 100 years unless ocean currents change again. Who knows? Just stop making these ridiculous suggestions without any actual thought before making them. You think you are being smart but you really look stupid saying them. 
  If the experts have no answers, and their job is to spend all day, every work day, to come up with realistic and affordable answers, what makes you think a suggestion with only a moments thought will be the answer?

text:
The only thing that doesn't change is constant change. Adapt or become extinct. Do the compulsory indoctrination camps teach that? No! They induce fear then use that fear to teach dependency. If school benefited the students it wouldn't need to be mandatory. For example, do group activities teach cooperation or obedience, independence or submission to authority? Every day starts with a prayer. Is begging God to save you a good plan? It's false hope.¬†
I started every day with a compulsory "Pledge of Allegiance". When I refused to join into what my teacher called "an acknowledgment of our freedom" because it seemed contradictory to force me if I was free, I was expelled. But the contradiction was not explained or addressed. The authorities showed their true colors, resorting to punishment, or what they believed was such. I loved staying at home, reading the encyclopedia, fiction, comics. I could direct my education by what interested me, not have it forced on me. That's freedom.     
Do the schools teach thinking? None do. Children are NOT taught to seek the truth but they are told what to believe. Thinking is not encouraged, in fact, it is punished. Self-help, adaptation to your circumstances, independent action based on personal experiences create a sovereign person. Ask yourself: Did the public school teach you how to become an independent (sovereign) person? Or, a citizen, i.e., a slave to the majority will or the laws of the oligarchy?¬†
Think about that, if you ever learned how to think.

text: ¬†@Calys Agora¬† - I read the NASA Survey. Re-greening doesn't mean that the disastrous impacts of increased CO2 don't exist. Your attitude is equivalent to someone saying "Forest fires are great, bc they provide us with heat and ash". Use common sense, one positive outcome does not cancel out other negative impacts. According to the survey you mentioned: While rising carbon dioxide concentrations in the air can be beneficial for plants, it is also the chief culprit of climate change. The gas, which traps heat in Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, has been increasing since the industrial age due to the burning of oil, gas, coal and wood for energy and is continuing to reach concentrations not seen in at least 500,000 years. The impacts of climate change include global warming, rising sea levels, melting glaciers and sea ice as well as more severe weather events. The beneficial impacts of carbon dioxide on plants may also be LIMITED, said co-author Dr. Philippe Ciais, associate director of the Laboratory of Climate and Environmental Sciences, Gif-suv-Yvette, France. ‚ÄúStudies have shown that plants acclimatize, or adjust, to rising carbon dioxide concentration and the fertilization effect diminishes over time.‚Äù
author: YourMajesty143

text:
¬†@Calys Agora¬† - Lol you're worried about tax? The amount of taxes you pay to subsidize the environmental costs of the fossil fuel industries and meat industries are in the hundreds of dollars annually, whereas environmental taxes are typically pennies on the dollar. Even with an increase in carbon taxes, it would STILL be cheaper on your pocket, than to continue the current system that "pick-pockets" your wallet. Man, they've got you brainwashed good. The best defense these industries have are folks who are scientifically-ignorant and emotionally-biased. 

FYI I'm non-partisan, I can't stand either the Dems or the GOP. But one thing's for sure is that climate awareness is NOT a political issue, it's a socioeconomic problem that affects all sides. Btw the taxes that would support environmental programs aren't just for climate change, they're for cleaner air, cleaner water, prevention of land desertification & soil erosion, protection of endangered species proper disposal of trash, proper nuclear waste disposal, proper regulation of industry waste like farm manure, proper inspections of ecohazardous industries, prevention of trespassing on Native reservations for exploitative fracking, better defense systems against wildfires, floods, hurricanes, etc. 

^ALL of these things (and others that I haven't mentioned) have been greatly underfunded for the past 2 terms. You can't be stupid enough to tell me that you're ok with manure running off into your drinking water, or a nuclear plant storing radioactive material in your neighboring town, or the your city not having clean air regulations. Bc that's what environmental taxes are for, smart-ass.

text:
¬†@Someone Else¬† Climate change is a constant. Climate same would be very bad. There has been global warming since the little ice age, a VERY constant and slow warming from a record low point that climate alarmist scam artists likes to use as the starting point for their pseudo-scientific graphs, conveniently doing away with the Much warmer period prior, with Much higher CO2, while showing ZERO correlation between CO2 and warming. 

YOU are the narrow-minded easily fooled populist moron that absolutely DID NOT look at the science or listen to the ACTUAL climate specialists at all, but mindlessly regurgitate the political propaganda used by TV hosts and mass media. I SERIOUSLY doubt that you have done your due diligence in looking at the actual studies, actual data or the judgement of people specializing in quality assessment of the scientific integrity and methodology, like Tony Heller. 

There is absolutely ZERO support for the claim that CO2 has ANY effect on temperature. what we DO now for a FACT is that CO2 makes plants grow faster, which we now KNOW for a FACT has RAPIDLY increased the amount of greening on this planet, and that this greening helps stabilize temperature and extreme weather, even though there has been ZERO increase in extreme weather events at all, but rather a measurable constant decline.  

Literally every single thing in Al Gores propaganda piece of shit fearmongering film claimed and predicted has been proven WRONG, just like every single other alarmist claim by "scientists" (LOL) has made in the last 200 years. Michael Manns infamous hockey-stick graph has been thoroughly debunked and proven to generate the same horrific predictions no matter what data you feed it. 

Is there in fact ANY claim by climate alarmist morons that you can stand behind and not have debunked by any remotely rational critical thinker hare? Just one. facts and sources needed to support your positive claim. i won't hold my breath though.
author: Calys Agora

text:
¬†@Someone Else¬† You are a shrill. Maybe go a read the research papers before global warming was propergated. Ice core samples show 1400 ppm co2 with temperatures the same as today. Think was a 1972 core sample paper. try and find on youtube or mass media. you wont. Have a look at nasa temperature data now they changed the temperatures that were recorded in the 1940's down because apparently their thermometers didnt record correctly. Australia showed a 0.2 decgree c less average over the last 30 years. But they also changed the 1940's data last year so now australia also shows 1 degree warming. Yes there is climate change as soon as you cut down a forest it will change the cloud structure around that area and wont rain as much there.
author: leigh Moom

author: leigh Moom

text:
¬†@leigh Moom¬† Exactly, I live in Spain in the Tabernas desert. It's been constantly getting dryer as plant-life dissappears witch consequently traps ever less dew and trigger ever less rain as a result in a vicious cycle and a downwards spiral,  which started with the Moors ruling the area and starting to  channeling water from nature into irrigation, drying up nature as a result.

Then the Romans took over and copied the Moors technology but added compulsive tilling and large infestation-prone monocrops plus large hurds of grazing goats who kept eating all young treelings which add salt to the cutting down of all hardwood to build warships and cooking firewood for an ever growing population. 

This was a tradition the Spainish kingdom followed by cutting down more trees for building the Spanish Armada. (This is also why we have almost no oak, book or ash forests left in Sweden where I come from)  Nature stopped recover here from the ever more often human created  forest fires, leading to this mountainous area having eroded due to the ever rarer and more intense flash floods generating what was previously fertile thick top soil to a clay soil with no organic content  and sand in the best case, but naked rock for the most part. 

THIS is man-made LOCAL climate change, and relatively informed individials keep assuming this once sub-tropic forrest was created by "Climate change" and most people have no clue it ever was any different than in the classic Hollywood studio Spaghetti Westerns famously recorded around here. Dusty, dry and mostly inert.

We live here and are loosing the last water in the last oasis to corporate high-intensity olive plantations irrigating millions of trees with hundreds of liters per tree pee day. We keep planting trees, and we got the nearby mountain top removal gypsum mine stopping it's operations as our house foundations cracked from their explosions. 

THIS is real, observable, undeniable large-scale human  habitat destruction, with very simple tangiable solutions that we need that is being ignored and blamed on this simple minded ignorant climate change garbage nonsense.

It drives me nuts listening to those uninformed collectivist critters that can't differentiate between a falsifiable theory and an unfalsifiable hypothesis, and thinks that fortune-tellers and consensus has anything to do with science, truth or reality.
author: Calys Agora

text: ¬†@BenjaminFranklin99¬† I don't know. But not doing anything fearing the mangroves itself will get submerged will be regarded just an excuse not to make a sincere effort to try and contain this problem.
author: Ridit Raj Dutta

text: ¬†@Ridit Raj Dutta¬†  Mangroves grow in brackish water, with their roots in the sea.   Mangroves protect the shore from waves when there is a constant sea level, but they have no effect at all on the sea level itself.  Do some reading.
author: BenjaminFranklin99

text: ¬†@BenjaminFranklin99¬†  I did some reading and learnt from this video also. The requirement is to increase the mangroves. Mangroves help check the soil erosion. You rather seem confused with your comments.
author: Ridit Raj Dutta

text: ¬†@Ridit Raj Dutta¬† Bluntly, you are wrong.  The problem is not soil erosion.  The problem is that the average sea level is getting higher, due to melting glaciers.  If the island were solid granite,with no soil to erode, the problem would be exactly the same.
author: BenjaminFranklin99

text: ¬†@BenjaminFranklin99¬† So why are the islanders planting the mangroves then? It does have a purpose. Please don't get confused.
author: Ridit Raj Dutta

text:
¬†@Ridit Raj Dutta¬†  I am not confused. You are ignorant, and worse, you are impervious to instruction, by me, a man with two university degrees and 68 years old.

Google "global warming," if you don't wish to continue making a fool of yourself in front of a global audience. Planting mangroves will temporarily reduce wave damage, but it will not cure the rising sea level problem. Mangroves are a temporary symptom reduction strategy, not a cure. That is why the country has bought land in Fiji on a high island.

Have you ever been on an atoll? I have visited many, including the island in the video. They are very low, about 3 meters above the average sea level. I have heard first hand accounts of people seeing other people being swept away by typhoons, because the giant waves washed over their atoll. People tied themselves to palm trees, but some were lost to the sea, even so. I have even sailed through a typhoon, and I consider myself lucky to have survived the experience.

I sailed my own little 10 meter sailboat to many places, including Fiji and Kiribati, on a long voyage from Seattle to Hong Kong, via the South Pacific, and I am a scientist, the chief scientist for a biotech company.  You probably had not even been born when I voyaged across the Pacific under sail.
author: BenjaminFranklin99

text:
¬†@BenjaminFranklin99¬† Respected Sir, where did you get the notion that I don't know about global warming? Where did you get the notion that I am looking for a permanent solution with plantation of mangroves alone? You missed my perspective. I am urging the giant corporations only to come to the aid of the people of Kiribati and lend a helping hand in whatever the local community is doing and thinking to be proper to address and thwart an imminent danger - may it be temporarily even.

With due respect to your work and position, which I am totally ignorant of, I humbly submit that I am not in any obligation to follow or serve your instructions. In any case, you may please give instructions to the concerned authorities as you may please and deem fit.

From the descriptions that you have provided about yourself and your works, I must acknowledge that you are an extremely courageous and adventurous person. May you enjoy good health, longevity and continue to pursue the good work. Cheers!
author: Ridit Raj Dutta

text: News Flash...The climate has always changed, it's not static. Ever hear of the Ice Age? It was warm before the Ice Age, got cold and warmed again...Always has, always will. Climate change is as normal an event or process as the wind blowing or the sun coming up abd guess what? Even that changes every day!!! When is the last time anything in your life has stayed the same one day to the next let alone over 30 years. Get real...If you don't want water in your house don't build on the side of the river or on a low lying barrier island or the lowest atoll in the world...

text:
Is there any actual PROOF this has been caused by ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù?  
No.  They just make the statement and therefore it is true.
I have family that has lived on a Florida Gulf key for more than 40 years.
Sometimes there is a 50 foot beach.  Some years there is none.
I‚Äôd be willing to be 10 years from now they will have their beach back.
Small islands like this have experienced this for thousands of years.   1000 years ago they may have blamed it on the Gods.  Now it‚Äôs ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù (which used to be called global warming until it was proven that the temperatures were not actually increasing, the polar bears were not dying and the ice caps were not melting). Now it‚Äôs ‚Äúclimate change‚Äù.
Almost every claim in ‚ÄúAn Inconvenient Truth‚Äô has not come true and has been disproven.
Yet people still buy this shit and others will continue to profit from the panic.

text: The level of the sea is not rising and what is happening here is nothing to do with climate change it is a very natural process that has been going on for as long as the water on earth has been in liquid form and it is called erosion every place that has a shoreline has the same problems that these Islanders have the only difference is that their land was lower to begin with to sea level and that they do not have the necessary infrastructure to prevent the erosion or to replace the sand that gets washed away by the inevitable storms that are a natural phenomena as well. In Florida after a Hurricane removes the beach we use big pumper ships to pump sand from off the shore back up onto shore restoring the land that was removed due to erosion. In Dubai they have created a chain of Islands that did not even exist at all using this technique. I am sick of people lying and pushing these natural phenomena on to weak minded youth as climate change to further a political agenda. If you live near a river or a creek the same kind of erosion and loss of land happens too unless countermeasures are taken it is not in any way climate change period.

text:
J√∂sses I‚Äôll try to make this less complicated for you.....ask anyone who has lived on a low level or sea level island for an extended period of time....beaches come and beaches go.
Most of the low level islands in the US are only still in existence because people have built sea walls and taken other steps to prevent further erosion.
However even sea walls won‚Äôt help if there is a direct hit by a hurricane.  If that happens, your house becomes a nice diving spot.  
This is not ‚Äòclimate change‚Äô (formerly known as global warming).  This is nature as it has always been.
It always amazes me that people are shocked when these islands flood.   
‚ÄúWe live on an island and have tried to build a sea wall out of coral and now our homes are flooding - must be climate change‚Äù
How about moving to higher land??

text:
how many of you problem solvers live in New York, the West Coast, the East Coast, the Southern coastal states?  All of these areas will, or have already started loosing land to rising waters.  (According to the experts in this field)  Perhaps your lack of concern and empathy is because you live in the center of this nation, and it's not your problem.  Being critical about their culture, and their family size, is nothing but a ridiculous deflection from the real root of the problem.  I didn't notice any starving children in this documentary.  What I did see were
 close knit families loving and caring for one another.  Men, women, and children taking proactive measures to save their homes and live better lives. As simplistic as this may sound to some of you, this way of life sure out shines the men in this country who disappear when they have made a child, or the mothers who take the lives of their children for a variety of reasons before they are born

text: It all hangs by such a fragile thread.  I really hope they persevere.  I was staying in a motel in the USA and a lady who cleaned the rooms I asked about her accent.  She said she was from south sea island that flooded with climate change and all had to move.  She ended up in Guam.  She married a US airforce soldier stationed in Guam.  He was head of maintenance in the motel.  I wonder if she was from Kiribati.  So sad many in the world today, millions more each year, are refugees from, NAFTA, wars fueled by the US aiding or selling weapons to, climate change, over population... and try to come to America.  They are only doing what anyone trying to survive would do.  Really I feel that most refugees would agree that their real wish would be to remain in their original culture and homeland, like the Central Americans and Mexicans, or the Rohinga (sp?) or those from Syria, or Africa, or Southeast Asia, anywhere, Kiribati...  Identity with culture, place, religion, language, all is very important and so sad many like here in the USA don't see that with the refugees of the world.  I saved a young man, only 19, from jumping off a bridge in my city in the USA.  He was from Somalia.  This doc is very important showing how a sense of place and culture is so important, a universal to the human condition.  I think of all the billionaires and how just a small desalination plant would help so many.  I saw how those children had to share pens to write with, and paper to do the drawings when everyone of them should have had pens and paper and a lot more.  Thanks for this documentary!

text:
¬†@Calys Agora¬† Did you actually watch and listen to the documentary? Or are you just another climate changer denier? Because that is a very uninformed, ignorant statement.  

The people of Kiribati are NOT responsible for the destruction of their country. More industrialised, and primarily Western countries are at fault here. 

This country is mostly made up of atolls, which are primarily low-lying and thus susceptible to flooding and eventual complete submersion underwater, this has already happened to some of Kiribati's islands due to the rising ocean levels as a result of climate change. 

I'm not here to argue, I'm just defending the people of that nation; how would you like it if your land began to disappear, the land you've lived on your entire life, and there was nothing you could do to stop it, and equally nothing you did to cause it to occur in the first place?

text: When you are forced out of your islands and doomed to raise your future generations as rootless- without any cultural homeland, and when you realize that you'll have no other choice but to raise your children on stories of a place that will no longer exist,  a place where you grew up in and love, when you will have to leave behind thousands of years of heritage and history to drown beneath the waves of rising sea levels and environmental corruption, then I will listen what you have to say. You are just plain wrong and have no idea what us Pacific Islanders in low lying atolls have to go through. It's true that many island civilizations started because of voyages across the ocean, but this isn't Moana. This is the 21st century, and you can't just move entire populations to another country.  Being a climate refugee isn't just as solvable and as simple as "migrating as our ancestors did." Immigration is so strict in so many countries. In the case of moving to America, because America has a lot of interdependence in Micronesia, President Trump barely respects war refugees seeking alyssum. There's a 0% chance of him and his stance on climate change being a hoax to bat an eye at us climate refugees. Few of us like myself are lucky enough to be able to move to the states, or to another 1st world country, even if it means living in conditions anywhere from lower-middle-class to poverty, mind you in a place that discriminates against you, like how many Micronesians (including, Kirbatians, Marshallese, Chuukese, Pompeians, and so many more) live in Hawaii and get people saying we should be eradicated because locals don't like us. A lot of people on the islands are poorly educated and live in extreme poverty and bad health because of the lack of funding in medical care and schooling. They are not suited for the environment of just uprooting their whole family and moving them to a different country where they can barely speak the language. We know that nothing stays the same, we know that things are always changing, it's just that our islands have to pay the price for unethical environmental decisions¬†from larger countries for the sake of that affects us. It doesn't affect the people who mad these decisions out of greed, it affects us. Natural changes and natural variability in the climate are not as drastic. The difference of this man-made climate change that you find so misleading is that the things we are doing to our earth by disrupting the natural carbon cycle with exhausting all our resources and releases unprecedented amounts of carbon emissions. Anyway, since you seem so knowledgable in the migrations of my people, do tell me, where do you suggest these thousands of people worth of population should move to, just since you brought it up ü§∑üèΩ

text:
I stopped watching because it is too daft: Fact is that the scientifically agreed sea-level rise numbers are between 1.3mm - 3.2mm annually. If you don't believe me check that yourself. 

If the walls are under attack from waves that have risen by 75cm in 30 years then that is due to storms/currents/el nino and geological activity... what this German documentary is saying is that because sea level may have risen 7cm in the last 30 years, it is therefore causing waves to rise by over 60 cm in that same time. Nope, sorry German hysteria peddlers but that just doesn't make sense.  

Even if we take the most alarmist science data on sea level rise : https://www.abc.net.au/news/science/2018-02-13/25-years-of-satellite-data-confirms-global-sea-level-rise-rate/9416570  then the waves Kiribati is receiving cannot be caused by sea-level rise from man made climate change. 

I'm really getting sick of every event being blamed on man made climate change and what angers me even more is when leftwits in media jobs use hysteria to push for higher taxation.

text:
This makes me think of a sand castle built close to the waves.  A wave comes along and wipes some of the sand away. Then some of that castle wall collapses closer to the water and regular waves and larger waves come up and pull even more sand away, which causes more collapse, etc. I believe in climate change; the natural cycles and people speeding up that cycle, but I don‚Äôt think this is from climate change at all. 
These people caused some of it themselves.  Having so many kids causes resources such as trees to be used up more quickly in order to build larger homes (I don‚Äôt see many mature trees), which speeds up erosion. They also are using boat engines, cars, gasoline, oil, and wood fuel thereby contributing to change. Plus, their use of plastics and all the garbage floating around can‚Äôt help.

text:
I‚Äôm saddened and sickened by the attitude of so many of the comments on here. The eagerness to blame the Gilbertese people for their plight speaks to a callous indifference, an ill will even, which I feel is horrifying. The casual dismissal of any Western responsibility, for the clearly visible effects that AGW is wreaking, bodes badly for world cooperation to mitigate its effects. The attitudes displayed by so many here will lead us to war, instead.

Some salient points:
1.     There is an almost universal consensus amongst the world‚Äôs scientific community that our climate is changing at an extremely rapid pace, and that this is being driven, to a very large extent, by human created pollution.The only dissenting scientific voices seem to be those employed in the petrochemical industry which, of course, has huge resources for publicising this dissent.
2.      On a per capita basis, a number of the middle eastern oil producers are the highest polluters, but Australia, USA and Canada come in at # 11, 12 and 14 respectively, with around 15 tons of carbon emissions per head per year. The average for the whole world is 4.9 tons.
3.      The EU, as a whole is at #49 and 8.6 tons.
4.       China is #55 at 7.2 tons, but it is important to note that much of this pollution is created producing goods for consumption by other people.
5.       Kiribati is #183 and produces just 0.6tons per head per year.

We, none of us, get to chose where we are born. Nor do we get a choice over where we spend our formative years. And for the vast majority of those living in places like Kiribati finding a place to move to is not a simple task. 
Some compassion and humility would be in order.
author: Q. E. D.

text:
¬†@Brady¬† If by "some scientist" you mean 99.94% of peer reviewed scientific research. And that less than 1% of studies that contradict the consensus not only are not peer reviewed but have clear paper trails leading back to fossil fuel corporations, you know the sole people who (temporarily) benefit from denying climate change, surely there's no conflicting interests in these studies that don't want to be peer reviewed, what could possibly give someone that idea. Which if you don't know, peer reviewed means these studies are analyzed and scrutinized by other scientists whose goal is to try to find flaws and cracks in the study, in order to make sure the data is accurate and the study overall stands up to the scientific method so if it is peer reviewed the average person who knows nothing of science can actual trust the findings. Which also means that when that sliver of studies that goes against the consensus fails to be peer reviewed, that kills their credibility. 
You then call people who support science "religious"... Okay, just because you fail to grasp that systematic observation, analysis, and experimentation (which is the core of what science is) is the literal opposite of a "religious belief" does not make your opinion true. In reality, quite the opposite, you just admitted your opinion is devoid of facts, logic, and anything substantial.
author: Drew Myself

text: ¬†@Voiceoftruth K¬† You mock others for not having logic and reason when your own is completely devoid of it. Are you trolling or just that stupid? "No other coasts experiencing higher water"? Yes there are, thousands of them around the world. Just because you're completely ignorant of the topic doesn't mean the problem isn't real. You want American examples? The island of Manhattan and the Everglades are two iconic places that will be decimated by rising waters. Even Trump built a sea wall around one of his own golf courses located on the coast, citing rising water levels due to climate change as the reason. There's nothing supporting your arguments except a willing detachment from reality.

text:
Didn't expect all the negative comments, guess I shouldn't be surprised though; when American's are confronted with the way that foreign media take climate change to be an objective fact, and not a political football, their natural response is to see the video as 'preaching' when it's simply relating what Deutsche Welle found reporting on Kiribati. 

As to the question 'why are they on Kiribati in the first place, isn't it to promulgate the climate change conspiracy?' I would just like to say: 
1. Could you deniers just for a second appreciate the obvious fact, that if you thought Anthropogenic Global Warming was real you would regard it as an important event? Might not disparate stories become interesting solely because of their connection to this epochal event playing out in real time? 
2. The idea that global warming isn't happening, or isn't causing the climate change we are seeing, or that it's a natural/cyclical event is the result of fossil-fuel interests muddying the waters to protect their profits. The only reason it picked up traction in the U.S.A. is that denial of global warming was turned into a statement of political allegiance, and hence not open to rational debate. It's happening and we did it. You have been deceived. You are wrong, everyone who knows anything knows you're wrong. Embrace being wrong.

Then it was Global Cooling which morphed into Global Warming which has now become Climate Change and the Seas Are Rising. So dumb. Here is your proof. 40 years ago as a boy, I made a mark on my grandfather's pier going into the water at sea level. According to the National Park Service, the all time record highest air temperature of 134¬∞F (57¬∞C) was recorded at Death Valley on July 10, 1913. That was over 100 years ago. author: antje tautkus

text:
Considering some of the extremely selfish, and ignorant, comments below, I feel I should post this here:

The world naturally shifts and changes, but not as rapidly, or to such an extent, as humans are currently changing it. If you're sick of hearing about climate change - and I am, too - then you should be doing everything in your power to mitigate it's effects. It's already too late for us to stop it. We should have started mitigating the damage decades ago. We're already seeing increased natural disasters as a result of man-made climate change, and those are only going to become more prevalent. We're going to see massive changes in our lifetime (we've already started seeing them), and complete societies are going to become displaced, meaning more refugees will become dependent on wealthier, better situated societies. It's too late to stop it, but we can try to slow it down, or mitigate its effects. The alternative doesn't bear thinking about.

I know it can be hard for some people to accept personal responsibility for things, but we are all responsible for this. Pollute less, use greener products and technology, only purchase food that has been caught, or farmed in an ethical, environmentally responsible manner, and don't vote in politicians who care more about profit than the future of the planet, the environment, wildlife, and humanity.

Even if you don't believe in climate-change (and that's a really stupid, uneducated, uninformed, unethical, and illogical stance to take), it's not worth the risk. You might as well do the things mentioned above, because they're not only far more ethical, and better for humans, animals, and the environment, they're often more economically viable as well. You have no reason not to join the rest of humanity in this plight - especially if you live in the United States, a country that contributes far more than it's fair share of environmental destruction, pollution, and species extinction. 

And if you're wrong, your descendants are going to be the ones who suffer the most - and they'll curse you for your ignorance.

text:
No, climate change is happening exactly the way we predicted it would. Your comment belies both extreme scientific illiteracy, and misinformation, on your part. No one claims that the world has never changed. The problem is that man-made climate change is causing the world to warm up unnaturally rapidly and extensively. This is causing increased climate problems globally - flooding, severe, unpredictable, dangerous weather patterns, and environmental damage. We're already seeing all of this on an increased scale. On top of this, the earth has previously through five major extinctions - global extinctions, during which most of the species on earth died out. Humans are now causing the sixth major extinction, and it's only getting worse due to climate change. The effects of all this affect much more than just the environment - there are, and will continue to be, an increasing amount of food shortages, health problems, death due to natural disasters and extreme weather, and refugees as a result of the same (who will then be at the mercy of wealthier, and better situated countries' charity), and much, much more.

Try learning about the actual science, instead of listening to propaganda. You don't have to listen to Al Gore, or a random dude in a lab coat - just look at the actual data, because that's all that matters. All the available empirical evidence irrefutably demonstrates that we are in the midst of man-made climate change. And because of people like yourself, who don't do their due diligence, it's already too late to stop it. If we'd wanted to do that, we would have had to start decades ago. There's nothing we can do now to stop the chaos that we have wrought, but we can mitigate its effects...but only if we start ASAP, and even then, it may be too late. 

I know it can be hard for some people to accept personal responsibility for things, but we are all responsible for this. Pollute less, use greener products and technology, only purchase food that has been caught, or farmed in an ethical, environmentally responsible manner, and don't vote in politicians who care more about profit than the future of the planet, the environment, wildlife, and humanity.

Even if you don't believe in climate-change (and that's a really stupid, uneducated, uninformed, unethical, and illogical stance to take), it's not worth the risk. You might as well do the things mentioned above, because they're not only far more ethical, and better for humans, animals, and the environment, they're often more economically viable as well. You have no reason not to join the rest of humanity in this plight - especially if you live in the United States, a country that contributes far more than it's fair share of environmental destruction, pollution, and species extinction. 

And if you're wrong (and you're wrong), your descendants are going to be the ones who suffer the most - and they'll curse you for your wilful ignorance.

text:
What a narrow minded inaccurate statement. Their Ancestors navigated by sun, stars, sea currents, natural landmarks in the sea to travel thousands of miles. This happened while other Europeans Nations were scared they "would fall off the end of the flat earth".

It is the same "Westernization" of these cultures that are causing cultural changes are changing what people world wide are considering important. To own a TV, car, and other "Western" inventions are causing many small and resource rich under developed nations to sell their resources. This includes over logging, mining, oil production, people exploitation. Add to this mix the crushing debt payments to international banks which force countries to sell resources. The extraction of these resources adds to carbon loads, reduces forests, pollutes land and water, and increases populations. 

Restrictive alternatives, foolish tariffs, unavailability of birth control, limited education have dire consequences NOT ONLY FOR CLIMATE CHANGE but make countries like these ripe for terrorists organizations which can give people WHO ARE DESPERATE false hope and blame the same "Western" way of life in which you have so much pride.

READ the background information on countries like these and see what the State Department, CIA, DOD write about the effects of Climate Change on the destablization of nations. A hungry man is an angry man; a displaced family can grow CENTURIES of hostility and resentment. 

Climate Change is real. The consequences are MORE than rising sea levels and disappearing species. Open your eyes!!

text: This is a beautiful, irresponsible documentary. text:
Yes it would appear that as each high tide and storm surge hits, the sand, because of the loss of coral and rock formations is being washed away at faster and faster
rates. The so called Sea Walls that the people are attempting to build using the broken Corals are in themselves causing more and more of a problem, where in the past there would have been fields of low lying corals and rocks to slow and diffuse the tides and sea surges there is now only flat open plains for the sea to cover, and then leave with some sand on the next low tide. The whole area would now need huge amounts of large rock placed out on the now open plains to slow any more sand loss over time, and a lot more Mangrove plantings, then they could look at reclaiming the washed away land.The water tanks and solar are a fantastic start, now if only the locals can pick up the plastics and rubbish.

author: Josie Underdown

text:
I feel horrible for the people and their government. With no exports or industy on the islands the government does not have any financial resources to work with. They rely on mainly international aid for the existance. You can't tax a country with high unemployment. Most are scraping by without a real paycheck. The people, with basic donated equipment, can easily recycle the plastic rubbish found all over the islands into pavers, boards (for building walls, decking, home siding, railings, fences, etc, etc), and other items for everyday life. All it takes is simply equipment to melt the plastic and molding forms to put the warm placstic mush into to create bricks, road pavers, boards (just like Trex decking), etc, etc... There is a video showing one man doing that. Video link: https://youtu.be/xRxB6lyMNZ8 The government may be able to have plastic waste brought in from Hawaii or other countries to make products to build their seawalls. Old vehicles can be crushed (after they've been stripped of everything except the metal) and other inorganic rubbish can be used as fill to raise the land. The government and/or international aids organizations could hire dredging ships to reclaim the land and build up the atolls. Perhaps countries with dredging ships sitting idle may lend them to this beautiful island nation. The most important issue besides losing land is the constant flooding of their fresh water wells. The walls of the wells must be raised higher before doing anything else. They have concrete equipment on the island. The government could strike a deal with the concrete company to raise the well walls with a platform and stairs for the people to gain access to the wells. I'm shocked this wasn't done after the second or third time wells were flooded by seawater. Granted all of these solutions are only to extend the life of the island. Eventually, unless they continue to raise the land or build a levee around the each island the sea will raise too high to stop. A levee would require a breakwater to reduce the impact of waves on the levees and/or seawalls surrounding the islands.

It's a heartbreaking situation playing out like a slow motion catastrophe. And with the population increase now and the explosion of growth expected they either need to reclaim new land or ask volunteers to move to the new land they purchased. They do need some of the population to go to the new land to start development of the area keeping to keep their traditional way of life intact when they are forced to flee there. Otherwise the land may end up being developed like a western town or village. They risk losing their cultural identity. So long as it is developed to resemble their current lives, with the addition of modern amenities like plumbing and solar electricity, abandoning the island will be an easier transition.

text:
This is what REALLY Kiribati is all ABOUT!!! 
https://www.worldnomads.com/travel-safety/oceania/kiribati/kiribati-crime-and-local-issues
Alcoholism is rife on the atolls, and many of their inhabitants are "bad" drunks who may be friendly when sober, but out of control when they've imbibed. Drinking is one of the only nighttime activities in which to take part in Kiribati, and locals who do it to excess can get rowdy and violent. Walking around at night, especially in Betio, in downtown Tarawa, and on the beaches of South Tarawa can welcome random attacks and arguments thanks to drunkenness. It's not uncommon to see bus drivers and other workers drunk on the job as well. Kiribati carries some of the highest rates of mental, physical and sexual abuse against women in the world. Roughly 68 percent of Kiribati women report suffering domestic abuse at some point in their lives. World organizations have begun trying to put more aid in place for domestic violence victims, educate the community and lower abuse rates, but it's still a problem you might hear or see on your 
trip.http://www.nationmaster.com/country-info/profiles/Kiribati/Crime

text:
Ice melt does not raise sea levels,
Assume there is an ice cube in a glass of water. When the ice cube melts, will the water level have risen, fallen, or remained the same? Why? 

In the first state, we have an ice cube of mass m floating in the water. If it is floating (in equilibrium), it will have to displace enough water to support its weight. How much is that? It is just Volume = m/d , where m is the mass of the ice cube, and d is the density of water. 

In the second state, where the ice has melted, it turns into water of volume.... Volume = m/d! exactly the same volume as it displaced before. So the added volume is the same, so the level of the water will not change. 

As a matter of fact, as long as objects are floating (i.e. they don't rest on the bottom) they displace enough water to support their mass. Since by turning from solid to liquid, the mass of water does not change (well, maybe it does, due to mass-energy equivalence, but that's really negligible) it will keep displacing the same amount of water. 

However, note that this may not apply to everything. If you had solid alcohol floating in water, when it melts, the level would drop, because water and alcohol mix at the molecular level; i.e. water filling spaces among alcohol molecules. Yasar Safkan, Ph.D.,

text: I can't help but think of the old dredgers that  are used to keep the deep water channels at the required depths and steel Harbour piling to form a bulwark against erosion-The dredgers would bring back the eroded sand/soil to build against the landward side of the piling and stabilise the land by eventually raising the soil level.----Simplistic, I realise but long term,useful in replacing the soil/sand that is being eroded( I use the word "replacing" in it's literal sense) The water in the oceans is being drawn to the equatorial regions by the centrifugal action of our planets' rotation.To overcome this tendency we have two,maybe, three choices. Firstly, and improbable,Stop the planet rotating.SecondlyPrevent the destruction of the polar ice caps,and Thirdly,Using piling and dredging,raise the level of the soil of the islands.The second and third options offer the best chance of a permanent fix-And,in both cases, the old villain, money, or the lack of it, seems to me to be the main obstacle in the way of success-suggestions?

text:
Interesting viewing but very one sided and not as educational as it could/should be. 
No distinction between anthropogenic and natural climate change and no attempt to discuss geology and note that most of the largest atolls (Reed Bank, Macclesfield Bank, Rosalind Bank, etc.) vanished beneath the waves long before any possibility of human impact. No mention either that the highest point in Kiribati is nearly 300 feet above sea level (Banaba Island) which makes a nonsense of the repeated untruth that the (entire) country is "unlikely to exist in 50 years" - yes, that island has "political" issues, too, but the viewing audience is left totally ignorant of its existence because of the single "climate change" theme for 42 minutes...

text: Coming from the Hawaiian islands and studying Geology in the Pacific  , I have seen what looks like the rise of the seas changing. The truth is we are on one of the largest Crustal Plate, called the "Pacific Plate", while most islands And continents are on Tectonic Plates, Hawaii is in the middle of a crustal plate which sits on a hot spot. The continental drift is moving this plate, which are below the ocean surface. If you look at Hawaii as a whole, we have a total of eight major islands,  then many small islands , atolls, and reefs spanning over a thousand miles. Over time our islands have moved. Our islands formed and changed over time. I have experienced the shift of each island.  Big Island is still growing and active, producing another island next to it because the island is on a hot spot on the Pacific plate. The landscape is long and slopey. Little to none beaches, with lava landscape.  On the other major island to the left,  which is Kauai the mountains have eroded and have a lot of white sandy beaches. The next island Oahu where I am born and raised , is the same. We have maps and photos of what our islands looked like before. I remember seeing beaches , but they are now under water. We have many sandbars , while other  sandbars I used to see as a kid are not visible . Volcanic activity produce Earth quakes which help move the plate, with that it has moved our islands to left of the pacific, slightly up. All the smaller islands , atolls and reefs were much bigger  before but sank over time as it moved deeper and farther from the hot spot. You will see this pattern happen for all the other islands in the Pacific,  such as Kiribati which is below Hawaii and is also part of this Pacific crustal plate. Hope this all makes sense now. It is sad that it is happening,  but those who are from the islands have to either adapt or find other larger islands to live on. Aloha

text:
¬†@Andy Dina¬† Normal "sea level" (nominal equilibrium height of the oceans across the Earth) is primarily a function of the relative difference in water (vapor, liquid, and ice) that's in liquid form vs vapor/ice form. This means: any liquid water (within the Earth's gravitational field) tends/tries to get (flow/rain downwards) to the lowest points of the earth. Those "lowest regions" are what we call our oceans. All that liquid water settles to an equilibrium point -- which we call "nominal sea level". Tectonic plates do NOT rise/fall appreciably (except in edge subduction zones; even there they have little effect on "sea level").

Thus, the "height" of "sea level" (relative to the sea bed - which itself varies greatly and so is mostly not at a fixed height above the Earth's 3D center) is barely/insignificantly affected by tectonic ("land") activity. The height of "sea level" is almost entirely affected by where and how much water exists in ice/vapor form, all around the planet, vs. how much is in liquid form.  This means, the Percentage of solid (on land) + vapor (in atmosphere) composition of water (i.e., %-age in Polar/mountaintop regions plus %-age in clouds/air) ENTIRELY determines the level of the oceans (this level forms an equilibrium level, across the planet - we call this "sea level"). So only 2 things: Melting ice affects sea-level. And atmospheric + oceanic heat (causal cloud formation/rain) affects sea-level. Nothing else has any major effect on sea level on Earth.

text:
The world naturally shifts and changes, but not as rapidly, or to such an extent, as humans are currently changing it. If you're sick of hearing about climate change - and I am, too - then you should be doing everything in your power to mitigate it's effects. It's already too late for us to stop it. We should have started mitigating the damage decades ago. We're already seeing increased natural disasters as a result of man-made climate change, and those are only going to become more prevalent. We're going to see massive changes in our lifetime (we've already started seeing them), and complete societies are going to become displaced, meaning more refugees will become dependent on wealthier, better situated societies. It's too late to stop it, but we can try to slow it down, or mitigate its effects. The alternative doesn't bear thinking about.

I know it can be hard for some people to accept personal responsibility for things, but we are all responsible for this. Pollute less, use greener products and technology, only purchase food that has been caught, or farmed in an ethical, environmentally responsible manner, and don't vote in politicians who care more about profit than the future of the planet, the environment, wildlife, and humanity.

Even if you don't believe in climate-change (and that's a really stupid, uneducated, uninformed, unethical, and illogical stance to take), it's not worth the risk. You might as well do the things mentioned above, because they're not only far more ethical, and better for humans, animals, and the environment, they're often more economically viable as well. You have no reason not to join the rest of humanity in this plight - especially if you live in the United States, a country that contributes far more than it's fair share of environmental destruction, pollution, and species extinction. 

And if you're wrong, your descendants are going to be the ones who suffer the most - and they'll curse you for your ignorance.

text: Ya BUT it is Bull shit! The Island is sinking Not the sea is rising !  Coming from the Hawaiian islands and studying Geology in the Pacific  , I have seen what looks like the rise of the seas changing. The truth is we are on one of the largest Crustal Plate, called the "Pacific Plate", while most islands And continents are on Tectonic Plates, Hawaii is in the middle of a crustal plate which sits on a hot spot. The continental drift is moving this plate, which are below the ocean surface. If you look at Hawaii as a whole, we have a total of eight major islands,  then many small islands , atolls, and reefs spanning over a thousand miles. Over time our islands have moved. Our islands formed and changed over time. I have experienced the shift of each island.  Big Island is still growing and active, producing another island next to it because the island is on a hot spot on the Pacific plate. The landscape is long and slopey. Little to none beaches, with lava landscape.  On the other major island to the left,  which is Kauai the mountains have eroded and have a lot of white sandy beaches. The next island Oahu where I am born and raised , is the same. We have maps and photos of what our islands looked like before. I remember seeing beaches , but they are now under water. We have many sandbars , while other  sandbars I used to see as a kid are not visible . Volcanic activity produce Earth quakes which help move the plate, with that it has moved our islands to left of the pacific, slightly up. All the smaller islands , atolls and reefs were much bigger  before but sank over time as it moved deeper and farther from the hot spot. You will see this pattern happen for all the other islands in the Pacific,  such as Kiribati which is below Hawaii and is also part of this Pacific crustal plate. Hope this all makes sense now. It is sad that it is happening,  but those who are from the islands have to either adapt or find other larger islands to live on. Aloha

text: The history of our planet is one of global climactic change - for millions of years. Our greenhouse gases may be accelerating it, and yes we need to be good stewards of the earth - but it is coming regardless!!! The geologic record shows sea levels have changed by hundreds of feet all over the planet - areas like Utah in the US now high and dry used to be way below sea level....cities found dozens to hundreds of feet beneath the seas, long before humans were contributing any green house gasses. The planet is a giant recycling system - the Plate Techtonics models prove this amazingly clearly - the movement of the plates drags some regions down under the mantle, while new areas arise. It is is criminal to teach these innocent young people that this is human created and can be stopped! It is nature, and we may have a tiny impact on it if we clean up our act, but the change is healthy and inevitable - it is how the earth maintains itself. Building walls and planting mangrove trees may postpone having to move for a while, but nothing will stop mother earth in her evolution.

text:
These Islands have always been vulnerable to the Pacific Ocean. They are not sustainable for increasing numbers of people. If fresh water is pumped from sub-surface, then the Islands may sink lower than sea level. The Islands also sit upon island arcs or other up thrusts from the Ocean Floor. Thus the Islands may rise or fall due to tectonic shifts far away, or magmatic events. Climatic changes influenced by solar cycles will also affect sea movements and thus erosion. What these people need, is a friendly neighbour to take them in - a neighbour with high ground and space! AUSTRALIA!!!! Or New Zealand! Who would want to go to the USA?

Whether CO2 is a cause of climate change is a moot point, but even if it is, it is too late for these island people! Someone needs to give them a home! SOON!!!!

text:
Human beings believe that the laws of nature do not apply. Mankind is in for a rude awakening as ecological conditions continue to get worse. The subject of Ocean Acidification was not discussed. As the ocean's convert into carbonic acid, coral reefs are dying- some 80% of the Great Barrier Reef is now dead or dying due to coral bleaching.¬†
The essential problem is too many people and too few resources. Every 365 days the global human population expands by a further 84 million. It now takes just 12 years for the human population to grow by a further 1 billion. Unlimited population growth would not be a problem except for one "tiny" problem- we live in a world with physical limits.
When the epitaph is written for humanity it will read: 'Cleaver primate, although selfish, greedy, and fatally lacking in wisdom. ¬†
"I'd like to share a revelation I had during my time here. It came to me when I tried to classify your species. I realized that you're not actually mammals. Every mammal on this planet instinctively develops a natural equilibrium with the surrounding environment but you humans do not. You move to an area, you multiply, and consume until every natural resource is exhausted. The only way you can survive is to spread to another area. There is another organism on this planet that follows the same pattern. Do you know what it is? A virus. Human beings are the most pernicious pathogen to have ever existed. text: Thank you.   It's funny how the climate cultists ignore their "zero sum" assertions they apply to taxation so easily [you know the mantra: if one gets rich, another gets poorer denouncement of wealth creation that clings to some notion from the dark ages].   So... any claimant of seas rising from climate change also needs to prove they know the total mass of land based ice on the planet and also prove it's dwindling.   That's about impossible:  at best we can estimate.  Sea borne ice flows melting would actually make sea level drop - but they don't differentiate, do they?  No - sea ice gets lumped into land ice fairly regularly.   If I remember correctly, it takes a land based ice mass of about 4,000 feet high the size of Greenland to raise ocean level 5 feet.   That does not include minor losses likely to occur as with more surface area of oceans, we can expect more evaporation and higher atmospheric moisture.  And with higher moisture, there will be more rain, which will cool off the atmosphere, and make more snowpack somewhere.   We are... air conditioned: the world is a giant swamp cooler.

text: I will be plain here!  The situation is geologically the atoll is sinking.  It was going to sink on trends that developed as soon as the volcano that built the atoll quit erupting and started eroding. It isn't climate change it is it is just normal erosion and rise and fall of atolls. That is why they are atolls.   The volcanic process causes very tall mountains above the sea.  Then the sea erodes the mountain and the center collapses as the volcano cools.  This forms the lagoon and then it forms the atoll.   Then the land further sinks until it disappears beneath the sea.   It happens all the time.  It isn't some climate change it isn't even a rising sea.  It is collapsing land which would do that even if no humans lived on earth.

text: China is building islands on atols in the South China Sea.  Hong Kong built their new multi-billion dollar airport on land reclaimed from the sea.  Holland has reclaimed land over the centuries.  The technology is there to help these people.  It is just a matter of the international community getting together to do it.  It would be extremely costly, and ultimately, a temporary fix as global warming and rising seas are real and here to stay, but land could be reclaimed and built up on Kiribati enough to allow its citizens to remain.  Maybe they would all have to leave for a while while the work was done, but ultimately it is possible to save these atols and turn them into sustainable islands.
author: Stone W

text:
Just starting to watch the documentary.  First thing that strikes me is the people building coral walls to keep the sea out.  Yet by building these walls they exacerbate beach erosion.  The family of fishermen talk about their beach being gone and having to transport their boat over rocks.  Could very well be the product of the "coral fortress" they built to protect their home and property.  I studied geomorphology and am aware that levies, sea walls, and the like alter natural sedimentary processes, often leading to greater erosion in one area and deposition in another.  Of course, I understand why they do it, and that they feel they have no recourse.  But just might be that they lost their beach because of the wall they build as much as for the rising ocean.
Another issue, at the end they speak of the population doubling on the main atol, yet nowhere in the documentary is there anyone addressing this problem.  Maybe they should be talking more about birth control to limit family sizes as the resources and available land diminish and contamination and pollution increase.
author: Stone W

text: I just watched an ABC Australia documentary on the Marshall Islands/Bikini Atoll. Here's the problem with all of these islands. There is no evidence whatsoever that man is causing so-called Climate Change or can do anything whatsoever about it. There is evidence however of earth's climate changing throughout not only recorded human history but as long as earth has existed. There were always periods of warming and periods of cooling (ice ages even), and the cause is cycles of the sun and increased or decreased solar radiation. This is natural and will always happen, and there is nothing we can do about it. In the late 1960s/early 1970s,¬†a great number of scientists were worried we were about to enter and ice age:¬† http://bit.ly/2mATnW6¬†¬† There were apparently a lot of comments on the Marshall Islands video explaining the same thing I am, and so ABC decided to turn off comments (censorship) such that we can not even have a healthy debate on the issue.

text:
Amartya: 

Sorry, that is a what we within rational thinking call a non-sequitur. It's Latin for "that does not follow".

Sea levels rising is NOT a proof of man made global warming, it is only proof of a changing climate. 
Within serious unbiased science, we know that the sun is the main cause for these changes, followed by the magnetic shifts in earths liquid magma core ,the red hot molten rocks thing that those small crusts of solidified rock we call "continents" float on. 

Our sun, the things that does ALL the heating in the first place, and the 99.9% of earth that is literally a burning hell, is just SLIGHTLY more powerful and influential than our pathetic existence. 

These videos feeds a narrative that someone is guilty for this, and something has to be done to save these peoples homeland or something like that. No. Nature will have it's way, and humans will reallocate as they have over hundreds of thousands of years already.  

Those people building concrete walls are serious, and can overcome natures cruelty. I duly applaud them and wish them all luch and prosperity they can muster. But if they buy into the notion that someone is to blame, they will spend their lives miserable, bitter and resentful towards their own and other cultures for no reason, thinking they got robbed of their homes by other humans. Disgusting. 

Nature don't care about your "rights".
Blame games is not gonna solve anything.

I wonder who people think are making all these claims? 
Realize that the people calling themselves scientists and pushing the MMGW agenda on TV is NOT climate scientists. 

Bill Nye "the science guy" is NOT a scientist, OK? -he's a freaking mechanical engineer, like me. And he's not even that brilliant. A typical teacher.

text: I visited Christmas Island, Kiribati last June.  Locals on Christmas Island were in complete denial about rising sea levels and politicians I met there did not want me scaring anyone by talking about it.  Land in Fiji has been purchased but people there told me that it is only being used for farming.  Nobody wants to move because they want to stay in the home of their ancestors.  Tarawa is tiny compared to Christmas Island and is over populated.  There are about 100,000 people on Tarawa and only 5,000 on a Christmas Island which has a ton of space relatively speaking.  It too has a low altitude but not as low as Tarawa.

text: Climate change is a natural phenomena and not man made. There was a period in the Middle Ages that was warmer than today and that was before industrialized countries and " greenhouse gases" . We're in a natural warming trend. Sea levels will rise and more water vapor will form more clouds, blocking sunlight until there's a critical threshold hit and then we'll cool to an ice age. It's been the same through the entire geological record. Don't buy the hype. And if you do your research you'll realize that there has been no significant rate of increase  in rising water levels in20 years. Just another scare tactic to keep the masses in a state of fear.

text: My heart breaks for these people. I hope and pray that they can save their home and culture. It makes me sick when I think of the way this planet and its natural resources are being exploited and depleted all for the Mighty Dollar. I was born in 1969 I remember lining up to get gas and the car is getting smaller and smaller. That was probably the time we should have been really making some serious changes to the ways we live and the things that are important to all of us. The hippies said to love each other and to love our  Mother Earth but instead of listening to the message-hearing it- Nixon turned it into a War on Drugs. It really upsets me the mess we are leaving for future generations to have to deal with whatever we leave to them. Nature, the animals, the poor, and children, the ones with no rights and no value placed on them are the ones that suffer. I've often worried also about mining deep into this planet what if one side is mind harder and deeper and worse than another side will our planet start wobbling on its axis and shoot off into space? Things like this keep me up at night! Something's got to give and the right people need to be put in place to make the proper decisions for this planet as a whole. Instead of investing in armies and warfare and missiles and such we really need to be investing in this planet and every living thing on it. Until we do that I hate to think of what we're destined to become.

text: I only got to 6 min of this film and stopped watching it. Climate change is NOT a human construction or it's sole contributor! It's the world engine and mankind, despite our arrogance, has cause some changes in climate, but in no way have we slowed it or speed it up. We are ant's living on it and the world changes as it has always done. Sea levels go up and down, temperatures go up and down, mass extinctions happen all on there own. Long before mankind even had two brain cells to rub together. The world changed and that will continue long after we are gone. We are just another organism on this planet and are not that special to be exempted from the forces of mother nature. Mankind DOES NOT CONTROL NATURE! Mankind CANNOT CONTROL how hot or cold the Earth gets! Mankind CANNOT CONTROL how strong the winds blow or how much it rains or where it rains! If humanity as a whole stopped everything it did today of what climate change morons say we are doing to make all these changes. The world wouldn't even notice because that is how insignificant we are! Volcano's will still erupt, forest fires will still ravage vast hectors of land! Coastlines will still erode and be created because this world is ever changing as this world is ever changing it's position and the poles move which makes the ice caps move with it. The agriculture belt will shift as the desert belt shifts and the monsoon belts shifts with it. What was once lush fertile land turns into the opposite as deserts become fertile lands. Oceans and lake beds dry up and new oceans and lakes are created and so on. Our world didn't always look like the maps we grew up learning in school and it will not always be that way either. Because the world never stays the same! Not because human intervention, but because that is LIFE and humans HAVE NO CONTROL OVER IT!
author: The2tlc

text: fortunately sea levels have stabilized over the last couple years, they are now beginning to lower. thank god for these people the global warming propaganda was a lie...the sun is going into a cooling cycle - it is the driving force of climate change. Not humans and our suv's. All the planets in the solar system are undergoing massive changes - are humans to blame for changes in the solar system? How arrogant of mankind...Grand Solar Minimum data goes back millions of years, 2017 is the first year in the next cooling cycle and the planet will continue to cool over the next few 11yr cycles. The oceans expanded because of warmer waters during the last warming phase, now they're beginning to cool and recede as global temps begin to decline. NASA, NOAA and IPCC are all guilty of fudging the data, lying to us so politicians could enrich their lives thru carbon tax credits. Best resources for real scientific data is outside of the US agency's. John Casey and David Dilley, both former NOAA scientists have excellent data as well...
