DW Documentary .¬† Please search in wikipedia¬†¬† 'sea level rise'¬† and you will¬† find statistical¬† information. Since 1880 the sea level rised by 1,57 (!) mm per year. . The cumulative rise of thev sea level from 1880 till today is therefore 216 mm¬† (8.5 inch) in 137 years ! .¬†¬†¬† Note also the diagram line of the¬† sea level risel is straight and NOT L-Shape.¬† That means¬† A STADY INCREASE of +/_ 1.57 mm PER YEAR SINCE 1880. . Logic¬† would suggest that, by considering the nonexistence of a mineral oil industry in 1880,¬† mankind could not have any influence in the sea level increase.¬†¬† Furthermore, please look at the population growth¬† on that island since 1947.¬† 2600 people in 1947 and in 2015 already over 50000.¬† Thie massive population increase, including immigration and tourism, required a relentless boom in construction and infrastructure. All the¬† houses, hotels, waterdams, fillings to gain additional land,¬† roads etc were all¬† made of local sand and coral stones.¬† The living¬† corals were killed by overharvesting the coral riffs, the dead coral stones remove and used for construction. If they have flood now then it's because of all these careless constructions and not because of CO2 production on the other side of the world. text:
Blaming Asia is ridiculous. 
And ignorant. 

Chinese production is much cleaner thanthe obsolete industrial methods we still use in the west. They are leaping forward much faster than the west, building much more modern and ecological infrastructure for energy efficiency, water harvesting and treatment, radically reduced fossil fuel dependency, efficient high speed trains, etc. They have every right to rise to the same standards as the rest of us, and they're doing much less damage than the west did, growing up. 

In case after case where people are suffering droughts, floods etc, it is consistently where generations of poor people have used up the natural resources, worn down nature and wildlife, cut down all the trees for firewood for cooking, and grazed the lands with goats and alike, until there is no organic subsoil left. This has for example turned my home Spain, from what was once a tropical forest, into a semi desert where they record spaghetti westerns. Where ones, before Arab Moors ruled half this country,  there were green mountains and many rivers, which are now endless landscapes of naked rock, and dry valley beds ,frying in the sun, suitable only for wild goats and Hollywood productions. 

People have been destroying this planet for a LOOOONG time, and blaming ourselves, our parents and the last few decades of technical revolution for it is just inane and silly. You're being deluded by political news propaganda with a very nasty agenda, and it's not helping one bit. 

If you wanna fix the planet, stop blaming your neighbor and first clean your room, then your back yard, then the neighborhood, and so on. And see what part of the nature that sustains you have been tempered with in your life. 

Learn to plant trees, not make protest signs of them.
author: Calys Agora

text:
Trees from those areas are not of a quality that is in commercial demand for production. 

Typically where poor populations try and shift the blame for their situation onto some external entity, they are more often the problem, like entire villages daily collecting firewood for cooking, until there is nothing left to burn. This is what we call "tragedy of the commons", a VERY common theme in many islands history, and in many other places too. 

If you claim someone demanded they be cut down, especially if you want to make it an ethnicity blame game, you BETTER have some facts to back up such a claim with.

text: I'm homeschooled, and have been fortunate enough to travel throughout the South Pacific with my family.  This documentary is the most deceiving video I've ever watched.  All islands in the South Pacific go through a life cycle.  They start out as volcanos like Hawaii and Tahiti and have massive mountains that jut out of the sea. Then they form outer reefs that protect the island from waves and tides.  But, over time, the island sinks in the middle leaving only the outer reef.  That is what atolls are, remnants of outer reefs.  Eventually the atolls are eroded into the sea which ends the island's life.  The atoll in this video is simply at the end of its life and will soon be eroded away as well.  Humans can't fight nature, nature always wins.  What I hate about this video is they completely deceive not only the viewers, but also the islanders who think they can blame climate change and demand for a change.

The only human change is ecosystem destruction, not climate change. CO2 is the dumbest myth ever. All fearmonger-predictions about drastical changes due to human CO2 models has failed, not a single one have come true. 

The Etna volcano alone has released in order of thousands times more CO2 than humans. 
An Increase of heat leads in general to an increase of vapor, therefore humidity, rain and lots of plants, thriving in the increased CO2 levels, which the data shows, FOLLOWS the warming (not the other way around).

It is rather established science now that solar activity has a MUCH greater influence on earth temperature than anything that goes on on the planet itself. We can't predict it, and we just recently have sufficient data records to start making historical extrapolations from all the prior decades of science that has left external factors out entirely.

text:
Out of 13,950 peer-reviewed climate articles over 11 years, 24 rejected global warming. Most of the "papers" claiming to refute human generated climate change are issued by think tanks and not published in the competitive peer-reviewed journals. Moreover, those think tanks are often politically affiliate and - in many cases - were formerly associated with similar obstruction-denial campaigns that delayed consensus about the disease causing effects of tobacco... or earlier, the smog causing effects of auto pollution. 
The chief excuse offered by such folks, when shown the near universal scientific consensus? That scientists are herd-creatures, timidly following each other and grubbing climate grants. Such apologists have never met scientists, who are the most competitive humans, ever. So what's the next excuse for inaction?

text:
Just my humble thoughts: For the entire population to relocate, that is something they should never opt for as they will end up marginalized or exploited and their great culture will be lost forever. I suspect that big countries are thinking like this: "How much will we gain financially if we take in these people and take control of the vast ocean and atolls they possess?" If they think there is great profit in taking these people then they will take them in as climate refugees and started "developing" these submerged islands using geo-engineering and marine science knowledge. The people though will just be absorbed into the general population or they may be given land that is their least favorite.
     The people of Kiribati should instead train many of their young people to become engineers so they can find their own solutions to this problem of sea level rise and end up enjoying their paradise without having to relocate.
    There is a saying: "Where there's a will, there's a way!"

text: I don't like people who blame everything on climate change and who tell me that we are all going to die unless we pay more taxes. The sea is going up 20 cm every 100 years. With the miles thick and heavy ice sheet of the last ice age melting some parts of Norway went up about 800 meters. as a result some countries to the south might go down a bit. With this chain being barely above water and made out of beach sand there is just nothing to stop it from eroding away. Sad but true. Our planet has always changed and also changed long before humans was a factor. I live where there was a tropical sea once. Now it is a prairie and 35 degrees below zero.

text:
Thanks. In fact coast lines are dynamic too. Nature naturally takes beach sand away and deposits it well, all over: in the the bed and onto other islands.

 Should we even live on coastlines and atolls expecting permanence? 

That's why most remain uninhabited. They're great stopovers for resting, catching fish, hunting or trapping, but not as permanently inhabited places. They're too easily damaged by perm popoulations. 

Short term, seasonal visits by small bands with a purpose. Resupply and leave quickly.

Nineteenth century exploeres have discovered and mapped islands, returning only to discover they're gone. Not denying we have problems, but let's not make up fakse ones. The real ones suffice to feed the cause.

text:
Lascelle Crew - I'm speaking in terms of what we now understand. We don't know what the ancients knew. Ex: Archaeologists found evidence of crop rotation in China at a site over 5000 years old. Did that village understand soil.? IDK, but something prompted them to rotate the seeds seasonally. 

Did island nations observe the dynamic nature of coastlines? They observed ocean currents and other phenomenon. Knowing, however, doesn't always influence behavior. Today we know how disease is spread, but do we always wash our hands or use condoms? Perhaps ancient people's could be just as stubborn as we are today, governed by greed, not just need, deciding to ignore consequences until too late. Just Maybe.

text: glacier ice core samples have given scientists the ability to chart out carbon levels and the corresponding temperature for the past 800,000 years...  carbon goes up, temperature goes up and vice versa.  in the past 100 years the amount of carbon has risen to a level MUCH higher than it has EVER been in the past EIGHT HUNDRED THOUSAND YEARS and the temperature is rising right along with it.  It seems logical to think that the unusual weather being seen worldwide (including high temperature, storms, droughts, fires, floods and measurable sea level rise) is correlated with the amount of carbon gases in the atmosphere.  Ultimately, I don't see any motive or benefit for anybody to knowingly LIE about carbon/temperature/climate change...  but, I can think of a few Trillion reason$ to not only claim it's a hoax, but to aggressively attack the idea...  too many people have way too much to lose if a global energy shift occurred.  I don't know where some of you deniers are getting your information...  so here's a thought.  What if you're dead wrong and we do nothing when we could have?  on the flip side, if I'm wrong and we eventually develop several types of renewable energy, who suffers?

text: The planet is coming off the tail end of the most recent ice age.  There will be a few centuries of mild, temperate climate then the long road back towards the next ice age.  This is a continuous cycle, been going on for millions of years.  The cycling is tied to periodic sun activity which again cycles on a continuous bases.  This is nature.  It cannot be stopped or changed.  Yes, there are things we can do to lesson the impact, but we will never be able to change it.  Our biggest issue is not the burning of fossil fuels though this problem ranks up there in the top 2.  The real issue is over population.  There will be a time coming soon when the planet will not be able to support the amount of people requiring it's resources.  And the population increases are becoming exponentially getting worse as we proceed into the 22nd century.  Somehow in some way we must admit we have far too many people on this planet.  And each deforest action, each new chemical plant built to support human kind, each increase demand for more living space, each failed nuclear power plant continues to take more resources from our plant without putting anything back.  Human kind will be their own cause of destruction.  When will this happen, who knows.  It could be in the form of a super virus, a rouge asteroid, a wayward comet or a massive world war.  This will happen.  We just don't know when.  Our planet is over 4 billion years old.  Human kind has only been around for about 50000 years.  Do the math.  Be active in recycling.  Eat more vegetables, reconstruct aged living quarters instead of building new elsewhere.  And for heavens sake, stop having so many babies.  The population increase must stop and start going the other direction.  We are our own worst enemies.  But again, we a due a mass extinction event.  It is long overdue.  That is nature, that is life.

The climate change debate went nuclear Sunday over a whistleblower‚Äôs explosive allegation that the¬†National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association¬†manipulated data to advance a political agenda by hiding the global warming ‚Äúpause.‚Äù

In an article on the Climate Etc. blog,¬†John Bates, who retired last year as principal scientist of the National Climatic Data Center, accused the lead author of the 2015¬†NOAA¬†‚Äúpausebuster‚Äù report of trying to ‚Äúdiscredit‚Äù the hiatus through ‚Äúflagrant manipulation of scientific integrity guidelines and scientific publication standards.‚Äù

In addition,¬†Mr. Bates¬†told the Daily [U.K.] Mail that the report‚Äôs author, former¬†NOAA¬†National Centers for Environmental Information director¬†Thomas Karl, did so by ‚Äúinsisting on decisions and scientific choices that maximized warming and minimized documentation.‚Äù

‚ÄúGradually, in the months after [the report] came out, the evidence kept mounting that Tom Karl constantly had his ‚Äòthumb on the scale‚Äô ‚Äî in the documentation, scientific choices, and release of datasets ‚Äî in an effort to discredit the notion of a global warming hiatus and rush to time the publication of the paper to influence national and international deliberations on climate policy,‚Äù¬†Mr. Bates¬†said Saturday on Climate Etc.

The June 2015 report, ‚ÄúPossible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus,‚Äù which updated the ocean temperature record, was published six months before the U.N.‚Äôs¬†Paris¬†summit.

text:
coral Islands sink naturally, (due to seismic phenomena), but in a healthy reef system that is compensated by land-growth due to new reefs being broken into sand and that sand being washed ashore. here for whatever reason... more likely ocean pollution, but possibly water temperatures... the corals do not sufficiently compensate for the island sinking. soil erosion seems to be the main problem seen here, that could be or could not be due to a climatic increase in stormy weather.
oddly enough it is well possible that the amount of nutrients in the water (from fertilizer runoff) may have actually reduced the speed of the sinking of the top of the reef (too fast reef growth), which in turn could have caused the reef to generate less debris (running out of building surplus materials) and causing its land portion to sink.

text:
¬†@Gregory Lenz¬† 


5:34 (among so many many more)
Here you can clearly see the land just under the water. In these shots it shows the size is still as large,  but the topsoil  has been washed away. There is also damage to the top of the coral shelf, that is causing some sinking, but the sea level is not rising.


7:39
Hm, that's the driest, finest soil I've ever seen. 
No wonder the ocean washes it away.


'Kiribati, and Christmas Island, the largest Atoll in the world, will disappear, temporarily in geologic times it will be back.  soon....     It's about how we measure time frames.'
Interesting story. 
Just how long does it take for coral to grow? Then disappear? Then regrow? 
How, exactly, are the time periods, between events, calculated? 
Accuracy vs conjecture? 
Those would be some interesting tables to see indeed.
Oh, and how does a volcano sink back into the sea? Do you have a timetable for that event as well?
Or, perhaps, calculations over the past million years or so?


Story time is so entertaining.
Just stop trying to push it off as fact.

text: There was a time when your ancestors immigrated to the land you claim as yours... Simple fact all people originated from a common branch of people from another main continent at one time or another... It was the time of the great dispersion when people moved around the globe, a time when the sea level was even lower and people crossed on land bridges from the Eastern continent to what we now call the Western North American & South American continents... No one originally lived on the Northern American continent at first... It was simply settled by different people groups over different periods of time... Yes, even the Lakota's have their origins from the Eastern Continents from past ages... This is also why you see pyramid type structures all over the world, simply because in a distant past they people groups were all related from a common ancestor and they took the building design with them using for construction what ever materials were available in the areas...

text: Climate is by definition the prevailing weather. Climate itself is intrinsically change. "Climate change" is simply a term synonymous with "climate." Weather is so complex that we don't even have the understanding of it to reliably predict the weather from day to day. I watched news as Irma developed and progressed toward the U. S. mainland, and meteorologists with all their education and technology couldn't predict that hurricane's intensity or direction from hour to hour. There were so many variables, and everything was a guess. They made some close guesses. But if a close guess is the best prediction we can make of a storm only one hour into the future, how can we be sure we really understand weather over many years into the future. The reason it is so difficult is because the climate is continually in flux. Humans didn't cause the climate to start changing, nor can we stop it from changing.

text: Sergio:  Are YOU educated about climate change, ocean acidification, AGW, Arctic and Antarctic sea ice melting, Milankovitch cycles, Hadly cells, sea level rise, coral community structure and evolution? Do you know who proposed the first correct theory on atoll fornation?  I can answer these questions in a couple of minutes without thinking about them. Why? Because I wrote my doctoral dissertation on the evolution of Hawaiian coral community structure, have worked on ancient and modern reef investigations for 40+ years, monitored the drilling of hundreds of cores through reefs to study their internal structures, studied and worked on civil engineering projects on Heron Island, Australia, Guam, Majuro Atoll, offshore Jakarta, Indonesia, on six of the larger Hawaiian Islands, interpreted C14 data from reef cores, published and engineering geologic classification of coralline materials, and studied fossil rudisted reeefs in ,Mexico. I can assure you that AGW is real and causing climate change, including the melting of Arctic and Antarctic glaciers and sea ice to cause ocean warming to provide more energy to cause more intense tropical storms and hurricanes. author: Justin Hopkins

text:
It's not clear what is harming coral. Coral is also sensitive to minute amounts of sunscreen ingredients. We don't even have good pH measurements from before 1988.

However, what IS clear is that atolls are not threatened by sea level rise. They rise and fall with sea level over time. (Wind keeps them from getting very far above sea level; ground up coral and sand build up whenever they get lower.) 

FACT: Kiribati and most other atolls are growing, not shrinking. http://www.bbc.com/news/10222679 (that's a popular article describing a paywalled scientific study.)

Coral disappearing COULD be a problem. 

However, there's a bigger and more urgent problem: killing of reef fish. They grind coral into sand which helps form the atoll. Amazingly, one parrot fish generates from ~100-400 kg of sand annually! (Depends on size and other factors.)
